[pg. 204]

SYNTAX

The differences in Homeric and Attic syntax can best be learned by the careful study of some good work on Attic prose composition.

The article. In Attic Greek , , is regularly employed as the definite article (the), its absence ordinarily marking a noun as indefinite, as the war, war.

At times the article may be omitted, especially in poetry without marking the noun as indefinite.

At times it may represent the unemphatic possessive pronoun, as Cyrus, having leaped down from his chariot, put on his breastplate, and having mounted his horse took his javelins in his hands.

It may be employed, especially with adjectives and participles, in a generic sense, denoting a class, as man(kind), the good, anyone who wishes, the aged.

It may be used with proper names in familiar style, as Socrates.

It is used in a variety of ways to form substantives :

  • With adjectives and participles, as the rich, those present.

  • With possessive pronouns, as your people, our possessions, our affairs.

  • With genitives, as Thucydides, son of Olorus.

  • With locatives, as those (who fought) at Marathon and Salamis, affairs, things at home.

  • With adverbs, as the people of to-day, those of that time, those over there.

  • With prepositional phrases, as those in the city, the things (needful) for the war.

    • [pg. 205]

  • The neuter article is prefixed to any word or part of speech when considered merely as an expression, as the word , the (saying) "know thyself."

  • The neuter article in the singular, all cases, is used with the infinitive (articular infinitive), when emphasizing the substantive character of the infinitive. In this usage it is commonly translated by the English verbal noun in -ing, as (the act of) fighting bravely, to fight bravely, (nom.) writing, of writing, to, or for writing, (acc.) writing. NOTE. - The article is always thus used with the infinitive when the infinitive is construed with a preposition.

Verbal adjectives. - In addition to verbal adjectives in -, as found in Homer and denoting possibility, or merely as the equivalent of the perfect passive participle, Attic Greek has a verbal adjective in -, similarly formed, and used with (often omitted), expressing necessity or duty, and admitting of two constructions:

  • Personal (passive) construction. Only verbal nouns from transitive verbs can be thus employed, the verbal agreeing in gender and number with the subject. The agent is in the dative, as the state must be benefited by you, a man must not be honored before the truth.

  • Impersonal (active) construction. In this construction, which is more frequent, the verbal is active in meaning and stands in the neuter nominative, usually singular, while its object is in the case which the finite verb would govern. The agent, if expressed, is usually in the dative, but is sometimes in the accusative as if dependent upon , which has a meaning similar to that contained in these verbals, one must. Thus you must cultivate virtue, , , one must do favors for one's friends, benefit one's state, and care for one's cattle, he who desires to be happy must pursue and cultivate temperance.

[pg. 206]

in Attic. - Attic, which does not employ (), has the following unhomeric uses of :

  • With past tenses, apparently as present conditional, as it would be worth a great deal to be wealthy if joy were associated with it.

  • With past tenses it takes the place of the iteratives in -, which are not found in Attic Greek, as = , = .

  • The subjunctive with av is found in general statements which are valid also for the future, where English employs the indicative present, as ' , we are all mad when we are angry.

These sections, which are omitted from this book for the sake of brevity, refer to the standard Greek grammars. Those wishing to learn Attic Greek should now read some good Attic author, with a few sections from the grammar each day till the most important fundamentals of Attic Greek become thoroughly familiar. Bon voyage!

PHONOLOGY

[pg. 207]

The Greek alphabet has twenty-six letters:

FORM SOUND NAME (Greek) NAME (English)
a as in father (when short as in aha) alpha
b as in bite beta
g as in get (never soft as in oblige) gamma
d as in deal delta
e as in red , ( ) epsilon
F 1 w as in wine 1 () vau (digamma)
zd as in Ahura Mazda zeta
as in fte (open e) eta
th as in thick (originally t+h) theta
i as in machine (when short as i in hit) iota
k as in kill kappa
l as in English, but with a trill lambda
m as in met mu
n as in net nu
x as in wax () xi
o as in rose (Fr.), (closed o) , ( ) omicron
p as in pie () pi
1 k as in kale 1 koppa
Fr. or Ger. trilled r rho
2 s as in sit sigma
t as in tie tau
3 u as in prune (better as Fr. ou, sou) ( ) upsilon
ph as in sophomore (originally p+h) () phi
ch as in loch or doch (originally c+h) () chi
ps as in lips () psi
o as in or (open o) ( ) omega

1, 2, 3: see next page for footnotes.

[pg. 208]

Only the capitals were used in antiquity, the small letters being introduced by medieval copyists of Greek manuscripts.

The vowels are: , , , , , pure vowels, and , , , semi-vowels.

The diphthongs are:

  • pronounced as ai in aisle.
  • pronounced as ou in house (or rather as au in Ger. Haus).
  • pronounced as ei in freight (or better still, pronounce both vowels, + , but fuse them into a single syllable ei, with the accent on the first part).
  • pronounced as eh + oo in spoon, but fused into one syllable, somewhat as eu in Fr. fleur.
  • pronounced + ou in sou, but fused into one syllable.
  • pronounced o + .
  • pronounced o + .
  • pronounced as we in we (or rather as oui in Fr. Louise).
  • pronounced + ou in sou, but fused into one syllable.

The improper diphthongs are , , . These consist of a long vowel (, , ) with an iota (), called iota subscript, written beneath, unless the first of these vowels is a capital, in which case the iota is written in the line, as = = went.

[*]Whenever by inflection (626) or otherwise an iota follows immediately after , , or , it regularly becomes iota subscript (505), thus producing an improper diphthong.

These diphthongs are usually pronounced the same as , , and respectively, although in Homeric times the iota was probably sounded to some extent.

[1] and are not ordinarily printed in Greek texts to-day, but both were common in the earlier period of the language; and a knowledge of the use of vau (or digamma, as it is sometimes called) is necessary in order to understand the metre of Homer, as well as to explain many irregular forms. [2] at the end of a word; elsewhere , as you will save. [3]As French u, or German , in later, classical Greek. For this sound, round the lips as though to pronounce oo in spoon, and with them in this position pronounce long e in me.
[pg. 209]

PRONUNCIATION, CONSONANTS

, , and may be pronounced as indicated above. In Homeric times they were pronounced somewhat as t-h in fat-head, p-h in sap-head, and ck-h in thick-head, respectively, but without the break noticeable in English between the two syllables.

The remaining consonants may be pronounced as specified in the list, but before , , , , , is called gamma-nasal, and is pronounced as n in song, as uproar, pronounced clahngy.

Mutes. The letters , , ; , , ; , , are called mutes or stops.

They are divided into three classes, according to the part of the mouth most occupied in producing them:

  • Labial (lip) mutes (, , ), called -mutes.
  • Dental (teeth) mutes (, , ), called -mutes (called also lingual (tongue) mutes).
  • Palatal (palate) mutes (, , ) called -mutes (called also guttural (throat) mutes).

Mutes of the same class are called cognate, as being pronounced by the same organs of speech; lips (labials), tongue and teeth (linguals, dentals), or palate and throat (palatals, gutturals).

The mutes are also grouped in three orders, according to the relative amount of expiratory force employed in making them:

  • Smooth mutes (, , ), called tenues.
  • Middle mutes (, , ), called medials.
  • Rough mutes (, , ), called aspirates.

Mutes of the same order are said to be cordinate.

Nasals. The nasals are , , and -nasal (508).

They may also be divided into three classes, corresponding to the three classes of mutes:

  • a labial.
  • a dental (lingual).
  • -nasal a palatal (guttural).

Liquids. The liquids are and , to which are sometimes added the nasals, and .

[pg. 210]

Spirants. The spirants are and .

Double Consonants. The double consonants are (=zd), (= , , ), and (= , , ).

Quantity. The vowels and are always long; and o are always short, while , , and are sometimes long and sometimes short, and hence are called doubtful vowels.

When the doubtful vowels are long in this text, it will be indicated (except in the direct quotations from Homer) by their having the mark () placed over them, as goddess. This mark will not be placed over vowels having the circumflex accent (534), as they are always long (537).

Diphthongs, including improper diphthongs (505), are always long.

A syllable is long by nature when it contains a long vowel or a diphthong. It is long by position when its vowel is followed by two or more consonants, or by a double consonant (518).

One or both of the consonants which make a syllable long by position may come in the following word.

If a mute (509), followed by a liquid (516), or by the nasals or , comes after a short vowel, and the mute and liquid (or nasal) come within the same word or the same part of a compound, the syllable is common, that is, it may be either long or short, according to the requirements of the verse.

Sometimes, under the verse ictus (1183), a short vowel followed by , , or (occasionally or ) forms a syllable long by position, in which case these consonants seem to have been doubled in pronunciation, and are sometimes so written.

If and another consonant come after a short vowel, the syllable is common, i.e. either long or short (524). Such syllables are regularly long only under the verse ictus (1183, 1171, 1168); otherwise, usually short.

Breathings. Every vowel at the beginning of a word must have either the smooth breathing () or the rough breathing (), written over it if it is a small letter, and before it if it is an initial capital followed by small letters. If the entire word is written in capitals, the breathing is omitted.

[pg. 211]

QUANTITY, BREATHINGS, ACCENTS

The rough breathing, called aspiration, shows that h was sounded before the vowel, as loom, mast (pronounced histos).

Initial always has the rough breathing; initial usually has it.

The smooth breathing denotes that the vowel was sounded without the h, as my, mine (pronounced ems).

A diphthong, except an improper one (505) at the beginning of a word takes the breathing over its second vowel, as () self (pronounced owtos), () son (pronounced hws).

Improper diphthongs take the breathing over the first vowel when it is a small letter, and before it when it is an initial capital followed by small letters (505).

In compounds no word is written with a breathing unless it be initial, even though it originally had it, as ( + ) bring together, hearken to. In such cases the rough breathing should be pronounced.

Accents. There are three accents, the acute (), the grave (`), and the circumflex (), as a plan, a good plan, wrath.

These accents are all ordinarily pronounced alike, by stressing the accented syllable, as in English. In ancient Greek they seem to have represented a difference of pitch.

The acute accent can stand on one of the last three syllables only of a word, the circumflex on one of the last two only, and the grave on the last only.

The circumflex accent can stand only over a long vowel or a diphthong.

If diphthongs (except improper ones, 505) have either the accent or breathing, or both, these must come over the second vowel, as themselves, because, () this.

[pg. 212]

For improper diphthongs, these come over the first vowel if it is written in small letters, and before it if it is an initial capital followed by small letters (505).

If a vowel or a diphthong has both the accent and breathing, the acute and grave follow the breathing, while the circumflex is placed over the breathing, as king, protecting lord, afterward(s), thus he spoke, mightily, with might.

If the accented vowel is initial, the accent as well as the breathing stands over it if it is a small letter and before it if it is a capital followed by small letters, as to Hades, Olympus, grief, pain, woe.

If the entire word is written in capitals, both breathing and accent are omitted.

The last syllable of a word is called the ultima, the last but one the penult, and the last but two the antepenult.

The antepenult when accented must have the acute, but it cannot have the accent if the last syllable is long by nature (522), or ends in either of the double consonants or , as booty, but (gen.) of booty.

An accented penult has the circumflex if it is long by nature (522), while the ultima is short by nature, as sceptre.

An accented ultima may have the acute when short, as good, the acute or circumflex when long, as soul, (gen.) of a soul.

Final and are counted short when determining the accent, except in the optative and in (loc.) at home, as (545) words, (544) seas. These diphthongs are regularly long in metrical quantity, and must be so treated when reading the verse, although considered short when determining the accent.

Verbs regularly have the recessive accent, that is, their accent is thrown as far back to the left as the rules of accent will allow. For exceptions see 902.

ATHENA PARTHENOS

National Museum, Athens

A marble statuette copy of Athena by Phidias, placed in the Parthenon in 438 B.C. The original, nearly forty feet high, had ivory for the face, feet, and hands, and gold for the drapery and accessories.

Found at Athens in 1880.

 [pg. 213]

ACCENT, PROCLITICS, ENCLITICS

A word with the acute on the last syllable is called oxytone (sharp-toned).

Oxytones change the acute to the grave before other words, not separated by punctuation marks, in the same sentence, except before enclitics (553), elided syllables (575), or the interrogative pronoun , who? which? what? as up, up through, but up through the camp.

Proclitics. Some monosyllables have no accent of their own and are closely attached to the following word, as in his hands, where has no accent of its own, just as in the ordinary use of the (unemphatic) definite and indefinite article in English. These words in Greek are called proclitics, and are accented only

  • when followed by an enclitic (553);
  • at the end of a sentence;
  • () into, to, () out of, from, in, and as, when they follow the words they modify.

The proclitics are:

  • The forms , , , of the pronoun (usually called the "article," from its use in later Greek, 765, 481).
  • The prepositions () into, to, () out of, from, and in, except when they follow the word they modify.
  • The conjunctions if, and as, that (also a preposition to), except when it means thus, or when it follows its noun.
  • The adverb (, ) not, except at the end of a sentence.

Enclitics. An enclitic is a word which regularly loses its own accent, and is pronounced as if it were a part of the preceding word, as and for the birds, where () has lost its accent, which has become attached to the last syllable of the preceding word.

The enclitics are:

  • The personal pronouns , , , (), (), , (), , , , (), , , (), (), , , , .
  • The indefinite pronoun , some (one), any (one), something, anything, in all its forms (but not = ).
  • The indefinite adverbs (), , , , , , .
  • The present indicative of be, and of say (except , the 3d pl. of and possibly the second singular of ).
  • The particles , , , , (), (), , .
  • The pronominal suffix -de, the local suffix ("preposition") , and the adverbial suffix -de (as , ).
[*]When used as interrogatives, the pronouns , who? which? what? and the adverbs (), , , , , , , have the accent here given, which they never lose.
[pg. 214]

An enclitic does not lose its accent in the following cases:

  • When it is dissyllabic and follows a word which has the acute on the penult.
  • When the preceding vowel is elided (575).
  • When there is no preceding word.
  • When there is an emphasis on the enclitic.

() is written with an accent on the first syllable () when:

  • It comes at the beginning of a sentence or of a verse of poetry:
  • It denotes possibility or existence.
  • It is preceded by , , , , , , or .

When an enclitic is followed by one or more enclitics in the same sentence, each except the last receives the acute accent on its final syllable from the enclitic following.

When a word is compounded with an enclitic, it is accented as though they were separate, as ( + ), ( + ), ( + ), etc.

In the following cases the word before an enclitic keeps its own accent, and never changes the acute to the grave:

  • If it has an acute on the antepenult (543), or the circumflex on the penult (543), it adds an acute on the ultima (543) as a second accent.
  • If it has the acute on the penult (543), or the circumflex on the ultima (543), no change is made.
  • If it is a proclitic or an enclitic, it takes the acute on the ultima (543).
[*]Remember that two acute accents cannot stand on successive syllables.
[pg. 215]

ENCLITICS, SYLLABLES, ORTHOGRAPHY

Syllables. A Greek word has as many syllables as it has vowels and diphthongs. In dividing a word into syllables, single consonants, combinations of consonants which can begin a word, and a mute (509) followed by or are usually placed at the beginning of the syllable. Other combinations of consonants are divided, as -- man, -- quiver, -- to fight, - I have, -- sea, --- Agamemnon. Compound words are divided according to their original parts, as -- brought together (a compound of and , from = + = ---).

Movable Consonants. The following words are sometimes spelled with and sometimes without a final , called -movable:

  • All words (except ), ending in -, including - and -.
  • All verbs of the third person singular ending in -.
  • The third singular of the pluperfect ending in - (originally -, 584, 2; 585).
  • The verb , and the particles and , all of which are enclitics (553, 554).
  • The dative plural of the personal pronouns , , , .
  • The endings and , mostly adverbial.
  • The pronoun I.

This nu-movable comes regularly in all these words at the end of a line of poetry and at the end of a sentence, and always when the end of a verse coincides with the end of a sentence. Elsewhere the word may be spelled with or without it, according to the pleasure of the writer or the requirements of the verse.

Similarly some adverbs had a movable sigma at the end, as () often, and others ending in -(), ()(), (), (), (), (), (), (), (), (), ().

[pg. 216]

Variant Spellings. The following words were spelled at times with a single sigma, and at times the sigma was doubled:

  • The future and aorists of verbs with stems (630) ending in a short vowel, or in a short vowel followed by a consonant.
  • The ending of the dative plural of the third declension.
  • The words (), (), (), (), (), (), (), (), (), ()(), (), (), (), (), and () in all its cases.

In the same way, other words were spelled with a single or a double consonant, as (), (), (), ().

Many words beginning with , , , , and are often spelled with these letters doubled when they are brought before a short vowel by composition or inflection, as (, ), (), (), (), () (, ) (525).

[*]These letters were sometimes doubled in pronunciation, although it was not represented graphically (525, 526).

A few words were spelled with or without a final vowel:

  • -; (), (), () = ;
  • ; (), (), ().

The following words were spelled with and without or : (), (), (), (), ().

The following words were spelled with or without initial : (), (), (), (), (). See 603-604.

Some double forms are: () one; () earth, land, country; () drip, drop, pour; () loud-roaring, resounding; , together, with.

Variations in Quantity. Some words have a syllable which may be either long or short (sometimes, but not always, represented by a difference in spelling), according to metrical convenience (525, 1168), as (), (), (), (), (), (), (), (), (), (), (), ().

A diphthong or a long vowel, which precedes another vowel in the same word, is often shortened in pronunciation, as son (A, 499), where the meter requires the first syllable to be pronounced short. In the following examples the difference in pronunciation is indicated by the spelling also:

  • becomes
  • becomes
  • becomes
  • , , , , , becomes , , , , ,
  • becomes
  • becomes
  • becomes
  • *, *, etc. (nouns in -*) becomes , , etc. (nouns in -)

[pg. 217]

ORTHOGRAPHY, ELISION

Metathesis of Quantity. o and no often become by an exchange (metathesis) of quantity; that is, the long vowel (, ) becomes short (), while the short vowel (o) becomes long ().

The accent is not affected by metathesis of quantity, but remains as it was before the metathesis took place. Thus becomes , becomes , etc.

Elision. A short final vowel (very rarely the diphthongs and also) is regularly dropped when the next word begins with a vowel or a diphthong. This is called elision. An apostrophe () marks the omission, as (for ) having fillets, ( ) to arrive home, ( ) on his shoulders.

NOTE. When a final short vowel, preceded by one or more vowels in the same word, is elided, only the last vowel is lost, and the other vowels remain unchanged, as .

The most frequent occurrences of elision are in:

  • Words of one syllable ending in -e, as , , , .
  • Prepositions and conjunctions of two syllables, as , , , .
  • Some common adverbs, as , , , , , .

In the following words elision does not usually take place:

  • , , , , , and its compounds.
  • Monosyllables (except those ending in -e, and a very few others, as , , and (rarely) , , ).
  • Words ending in -.
[pg. 218]

Elision occurs also in the formation of compound words, but then without the apostrophe to mark it, as ( ) they shouted assent.

When the following word begins with a vowel, preceded by , elision does not ordinarily take place, as = in (our) home; but happily home(ward).

, a semi-vowel corresponding to Eng. w, thus varied between its consonantal and vocalic value (cf. 526).

A smooth mute (512) brought before a rough breathing (527) by elision (575) is changed to the cognate rough mute (511-512). Thus before a rough breathing becomes , becomes , and becomes , as and to reverence the priest, for ; quickly having summoned the hundred-handed (giant) into lofty Olympus, for , etc.; he sent (him) away, for -.

If an accented final syllable of a preposition or a conjunction is elided (575), the accent of the word is lost with the elided syllable. Other words so accented throw the accent back on the preceding syllable, but do not change the acute to the grave (534, 550).

Contraction. When one vowel follows another vowel in the same word, contraction sometimes (but not usually) takes place. When vowels are thus contracted, the following are the rules:

  • Vowels which regularly form diphthongs do so, as + =, + = , etc. [*]Observe that the long vowels , , , when followed by regularly form the improper diphthongs , , (505).
  • Two like sounds unite in the common long sound, that is, two a-sounds (), two e-sounds (, ), two i-sounds (), two o-sounds (, ), or two u-sounds (), unite to form the common long (, , , , ) sounds, except becomes , and oo becomes .
  • An o-sound absorbs an a-sound or an e-sound and becomes long o (), except gives , while becomes .
  • If an a-sound comes together with an e-sound, the one which comes first absorbs the other and becomes long (, ).
  • A vowel coming before a diphthong beginning with the same vowel may be absorbed, and may be absorbed before . In other cases a vowel before a diphthong may be contracted with the first vowel of the diphthong, a following iota becoming iota subscript (505), and a following disappearing.
[pg. 219]

ELISION, CONTRACTION, SYNIZESIS

TABLE OF CONTRACTIONS
+ = + = + = + = + =
+ = + = + = + = + =
+ = + = + = + = + =
+ = + = + = (rarely ) + = (rarely ) + =
+ = + = + = + = + =
+ = + = + = + = + =
+ = + = + = + = + =
+ = + = (rarely ) + = (rarely ) + = + =
+ = + = + = + =
+ = + = + = + =
+ = + = + = + =
+ = + = + = + =
+ = + =
+ =

Somewhat akin to contraction is synizesis, which takes place when two successive vowels which do not form a diphthong are pronounced as one syllable for the sake of the meter, as of the son of Peleus, where - must be pronounced as one syllable; may the gods grant, where is also pronounced as one syllable. Or the two syllables forming synizesis may come in separate words, as thus, pronounced as two syllables, or as again, pronounced as one syllable.

Crasis

A vowel or a diphthong which ends a word may be contracted and combined into a single syllable with the vowel which begins the word following. This is very rare in Homer. A coronis (') is usually placed over the syllable contracted, as the other (parts), for .

In crasis the first word loses its accent, while the accent of the second remains, which may change however from the acute to the circumflex, if the rules of accent require it, because of the long syllable which arises from it.

When two or more syllables are contracted into one, if either had an accent before contraction, the contracted syllable has one.

In the case of the contracted penult (543) or antepenult (543), the accent follows the regular rules.

A contracted ultima (543) takes the acute accent if it had the acute before contraction. If the penult (543) had the acute and is contracted with the ultima, the ultima takes the circumflex.

Syncope

Syncope is the suppression of a short vowel within a word, as ; why in the world? for .

Ablaut

In many words which are closely related occurs a change (sometimes disappearance) of the vowel, as in Eng. sing, sang, song, sung. This is known as Ablaut (Vowel Gradation).

Ablaut has strong grades and a weak grade, in the latter of which the vowel (sometimes) does not appear (disappearing grade).

The most important grades are:

STRONG

WEAK

1) , or
2) (usually in Homer),
3) , ,
4)
5) ,
6) ,

NOTE. (5) and (6) are really part of (1), being the short vowels , combined with and , forming the diphthongs , .

[pg. 221]

EXAMPLES

1) - missile, -- free-shooter, -- breaking in, shooting in, - shoot, hurl; - bear, - counsel-bearing, -- chariot (bearer, carrier), - quiver (arrow-carrier).

2) - (originally -, 621) I speak, - I lift up the voice, speak, -- he spoke.

3) -- I put, place, - fine (penalty placed upon one), -- we place; - I break, -- I broke, -- it was broken.

4) - gift, - gift.

5) - I leave, -- I have left, -- I left.

6) - I shall come, -- I have come, -- I came.

Sonant Consonants

In an earlier stage of the language, the liquids (, ) and , of the nasals were often vocalic (sonant); that is, they were used as vowels in certain combinations. In this case they are ordinarily written with a small circle underneath, to distinguish them from the consonantal , , , .

In Greek as we know the language:

  • 1) Vocalic (), becomes consonantal () and a strengthening vowel is developed either before or after, as I am sent, for an earlier ; were filled, for an earlier (); much, for an earlier .
  • 2) Similarly vocalic () becomes consonantal (), and a strengthening vowel is developed either before or after it, as , (= , , 621) heart, for an earlier , , strong, harsh, for an earlier .
  • 3) Vocalic () becomes short , as in ten, for an earlier , I loosed, for an earlier .
  • 4) Vocalic () also becomes short , as in the ending - of the accusative singular, and the ending - of the accusative plural, masculine and feminine, of the third declension, for an earlier - and -. Compare (acc. sing.) foot with Lat. pedem, which is for an earlier (pedm). It occurs commonly elsewhere, as they protect, for , deep, I suffered, for earlier , .

NOTE. Occasionally the vocalic nasals , (, ) became consonantal (, ), with or without the development of a strengthening vowel, as depth, woe, for earlier , .

[pg. 222]

In the case of the development of a short strengthening vowel, two spellings of the same word often arose, or else different forms of the same stem were used, as , strong, harsh; , heart; I hurled, I was hurled.

Consonantal . Many Greek words earlier had a consonantal (semi-vocalic) , sounded as i in onion, and written . Its loss when following the final consonant of the stem of a word caused the following changes in spelling: = ; , = ; , = (sometimes ); = between vowels; = after a vowel; = after a consonant; , , , = , , , ; , , , , , = , , , , , .

Compensative Lengthening

The loss of one or more consonants in a word usually occasions the lengthening of the preceding vowel. This is called compensative lengthening. When it takes place, , , = , , ; = ; = .

Consonantal .

(vau, digamma) was simply a consonantal (semi-vocalic) (just as w in English usually represents a consonantal u), and one often becomes the other in Greek, as may be seen from the declension of such forms as (*) king, ship, and (*) ox, cow, of which the genitives are , , (for an earlier , , ) (572). The final of the stem (630) of these words thus first became and was then lost.

NOTE. In a few words became and remained, as having taken away (= ), they drew up (the heads of the victims) (= = = ).

Loss of Sigma

The rough breathing (527) in Greek often represents a lost sigma. A sigma between two vowels usually became the rough breathing (compare the change of intervocalic s to r in early Latin) and was then lost.

[pg. 223]

Final Consonants

The only consonants which can stand at the end of a word are , , and (including and ). Other consonants coming at the end of a word are dropped, as house (for ); askance, scowlingly (for ); for . Cf. amat, amabat, etc.

() out of, from, and () not, are apparent exceptions, but as proclitics (551) they are attached closely to the following word.

, , not are the variant spellings for this word according as it comes before a consonant, a smooth breathing, or a rough breathing, respectively. At the end of a sentence, clause, or verse, the form is sometimes found.

Consonant Change

There are certain changes which some of the consonants undergo, mostly in the nature of assimilation, that is, a consonant becomes similar to, or the same as the consonant following (partial, or complete assimilation).

Thus () I fell has complete assimilation of the to the following , while in () I was conducted, sent, there is only partial assimilation.

The most important of these changes are:

  • 1) A labial (, , ), or a palatal (, , ) mute before a dental (, , ) mute must be of the same order (512).
    • [pg. 224]
  • 2) A dental (, , ) mute before another dental mute becomes .
  • 3) Before a labial mute (, , ) becomes , while the palatal mutes and regularly become gamma-nasal (508), and a dental mute (, , ) regularly becomes .
  • 4) Before : a labial mute (, , ) combines and becomes . a palatal mute (, , ) combines and becomes . a dental mute (, , ) is usually assimilated (608), becoming , and one is often dropped, as () = with his feet.
  • 5) before a labial mute (, , ) remains unchanged.
  • 6) before a labial mute (, , ) becomes . before a palatal mute (, , ) becomes gamma-nasal (508). before , is assimilated (608), becoming , or respectively.
  • 7) A smooth mute (512) before becomes a rough mute of the same class (510).
  • 8) + becomes ; or + becomes ; + = ; + = ; + = .
  • 9) + (when is final, or medial followed by another vowel) usually = , ().

NOTE.

before final becomes ; the is then dropped and the preceding vowel lengthened by compensation, 601, 613.

Thus, with the exception of (out of, from) in composition, the only combinations of mutes which can occur are , , , , , , , , and .

NOTE.

before , , , is a nasal (508, 515) and not a mute.

When is brought before by inflection (626) or composition, a is developed to assist the pronunciation. Similarly, when a is brought before (or ) a is developed, as , - () a man, of a man, (-, 597), immortal, () is a concern. For a similar development in English compare tender (Lat. tenerum), cinder (Lat. cinerem), number (Lat. numerum), humble (Lat. humilem).

, , , , , , before , and before are regularly dropped and the preceding vowel is lengthened by compensation (601).

[pg. 225]

In prepositional compounds, before , , or remains unchanged, while () before becomes -, and before + a consonant or before becomes -.

before is dropped and the preceding vowel lengthened, or else the is doubled, as () I am, () to be.

Words spelled with an initial have this letter regularly doubled when by composition or inflection it comes to stand after a vowel (not a diphthong).

, , , and are often doubled under similar conditions (525, 566).

between consonants, except in compounds, is dropped.

If a syllable begins with an aspiration (a rough breathing, or a rough mute , , ), the preceding syllable may not ordinarily have an aspiration, but becomes smooth, as () I put, place, () I nurture, () I shone, () I have. This is known as dissimilation.

NOTE. This rule is not always observed in the formation of the aorist passive, where two rough mutes may begin successive syllables.

Dialects

The Homeric poems are a mixture of two Greek dialects, Aeolic and Ionic, the bulk of the forms being Ionic. Certain apparent irregularities are due to the Aeolic element in them.

The long alpha () of the earlier language and found in most of the other Greek dialects regularly becomes in Ionic Greek, as desire, plan (). Long alpha in the Homeric poems is regularly due to contraction (584-585), to compensative lengthening (601), or else is an Aeolic form.

Punctuation

Greek punctuation differs from English in having the semicolon and the colon represented by a single dot above the line (), while the interrogation mark has the same form as the English semicolon (;).

Transliteration

So many Greek words have come into English through the medium of the Latin that the system of transliteration usually employed by the old Romans is the one commonly used for the mass of Greek words in our tongue.

[pg. 226]

This in general represented the Greek letters by their corresponding English equivalents. Those which differ at all were regularly transliterated as follows :

  • = z, as animal (zology, zon, epizotic).
  • = c, as ten (decalogue, decagon, decade).
  • = y, as fire (pyre, pyrotechnic(al), pyrography, pyrolatry).
  • = (a)e, as (stem ) child (pedagogue, paedobaptism, paedogenesis).
  • = e, i, ei, as hand (chirography), (idol), appearance (kaleidoscope), dwelling of the muses (museum).
  • = (o)e, as house, home (economy, ecology), like (hom(o)eopathy, homoeomorphous).
  • = u, as ox, cow (bucolic, Bucephalus, bucentaur, bucranium).
  • = eu, as well (euphony, eulogy, euphemism).
  • = rh, as flow (rhetoric, rheum(atism), catarrh).
    • -nasal (508)
  • = n, as messenger (angel(ic, -ology), evangel).

Iota-subscript (505) was usually omitted, as ode, Thrace. in Homeric Greek, when representing an in later (Attic) Greek (621), was often transliterated by a, as Hera, Athena. This rule applies especially to when following , , (462), or when final.

The following special rules apply to final endings :

  • = i, as Achaei, Danai.
  • = a (sometimes e) (621): Sparta, Ithaca, Hecat.
  • = us (sometimes os): Patroclus, Olympus; but Lemnos, Delos, etc.
  • = um, as Sunium, Palladium.
    • ,
  • = cy : democracy.
    • ,
  • = y, as Arcadia, Arcady, ( love, skill, wisdom), philosophy, literally = love of wisdom.
[pg. 227]

Greek proper names are transliterated according to the foregoing rules. They are put into the nominative (639), and are pronounced by ignoring the Greek accent and by accenting the penult (543) of the word if it is long (522) in Greek, otherwise the antepenult (543), as Lto, Olympus.

II. MORPHOLOGY

INFLECTION

Inflection, including declension (nouns, adjectives, pronouns), comparison (adjectives, adverbs), and conjugation, is the fusion of a so-called stem (630), and certain elements which express relationship to other words.

A root is the essential part of a word which remains after it has been analyzed into its various parts, and all prefixes, suffixes, and formative elements have been removed.

A stem often has more than one form, its different forms usually standing in ablaut (593-595) relation to each other. It is ordinarily derived from a root, by the addition of various formative elements, prefixes, and suffixes.

Some roots are also stems, and are combined directly with inflectional elements.

An inflected word is in general made up of two parts :

  • The fundamental part, or stem.
  • The inflectional element (usually an ending, commonly called a suffix; sometimes a prefix, as in the case of the augment, 830), which combines with the stem to form case, number, tense, person, etc.

The last letter of the stem is called the stem characteristic, and from this last letter stems are classified as vowel stems, mute (509) stems, liquid (516) stems, etc.

DECLENSION

Nouns

Nouns, pronouns, and adjectives are declined.

Number

There are three numbers in Greek, the singular denoting one, the dual denoting two (usually referring to a pair of [pg. 228] objects closely associated, or belonging together by nature and forming a closely related, unified group, as , , the two hands, eyes, horses. Compare yoke, team, pair in English), and the plural denoting more than two.

NOTE. - The plural is often used interchangeably with the dual to denote only two.

Gender

There are three genders, the masculine, feminine, and neuter.

The gender must usually be learned by observation, but in general:

  • 1) The names of males are masculine.
  • 2) The names of females are feminine.
  • 3) The names of rivers, winds, and months are usually masculine.
  • 4) The names of countries, towns, trees, and islands are usually feminine.
  • 5) Most nouns denoting qualities and conditions are feminine.

A few nouns are used either as masculine or feminine, as child, which may be of either gender, and may mean either boy or girl, as may be required by occasion. Such words are said to be of common gender.

The demonstrative (often relative, or personal) pronoun most extensively used in the Homeric poems is , , , the first form being masculine, the second feminine, and the third neuter.

The form of the noun which appears in the vocabulary is the nominative singular, unless otherwise indicated. This is followed by the ending of the genitive singular, which denotes to which declension the noun belongs. After the ending of the genitive singular is placed the appropriate form of this pronoun, to indicate the gender. Thus , , god is second declension masculine; , , wish, will, plan is first declension feminine, and , , pain, woe is third declension neuter.

Cases

There are five cases in Greek, the nominative, genitive, dative, accusative, and vocative, together with remnants of three lost cases, the locative, instrumental, and ablative (657).

[pg. 229]

All these cases except the nominative and vocative are called oblique cases.

Accent of Nouns

The accent of a noun usually remains in all the forms on the same syllable as in the nominative singular, or at least as near that syllable as the general rules of accent will allow. Thus hero (nominative singular), but of heroes (genitive plural). See 544 ff.

Words monosyllabic in the nominative singular, when becoming dissyllabic by declension, regularly have the accent on the final syllable in all the dissyllabic forms of the genitive and dative of all numbers, and on the penult of the dual (trisyllabic), but keep the accent on the first syllable in all other cases.

An accented ultima in general takes the acute, but in the genitive and dative of all numbers a long ultima, if accented, takes the circumflex, as soul (nom. sing.), but of a soul (gen. sing.), to, for a soul (dat. sing.), etc.

Declensions

Nouns are declined in two general ways:

  • 1) The vowel declension, for stems (630) ending in the pure vowels, , .
  • 2) The consonant declension, for stems ending in a consonant, or the semi-vowels, , .

The vowel declension has two forms, according as the noun stem ends in or . Hence we have:

  • 1) The declension, commonly called the first declension;
  • 2) The declension, commonly called the second declension.

The consonant declension, for stems ending in a semi-vowel (, , which were at times semi-consonantal) or a consonant, is commonly called the third declension.

Words of the first declension have stems ending in , which either becomes shortened in the nominative singular to , or else becomes (621), except in the one word goddess, and a very few proper names. Nouns of the first declension are either masculine or feminine.

Case Endings

To form the various cases, numbers, and genders, the following case endings were fused with the stems of substantives and adjectives:

[pg. 230]

Observe that the dative singular of all declensions ends in , which always becomes iota subscript (505) after long vowels (584, 1, note).

The dative plural regularly ends in , to which may be added nu-movable (561, 1).

- and - are the regular forms for the ending of the dative plural in the first two declensions. Occasionally the shorter forms, -, -, are found, but this is almost always before vowels, and it is possible that in that case they should be treated as examples of elision (575) and written -' and -'.

The genitive plural of all forms ends in -.

[pg. 232]

There are but two forms of the dual in each declension, one (masc. only) for the nominative, accusative, and vocative; the other for the genitive and dative.

NOTE. - The form of the gen. and dat. dual of the first declension is uncertain. Instead of -, some read - (-).

As in Latin, the vocative singular is often like the nominative, and the vocative plural of all forms is always like the nominative plural.

The nominative, accusative, and vocative of all neuters are alike, and in the plural end in short -a.

In an earlier stage of the language there were three other cases: the instrumental, denoting instrument, means, manner, etc., the locative, denoting the place where, and the ablative, denoting separation, source, etc. There are only remnants of these left in Greek, as the dative became fused with the instrumental and locative, taking over most of their uses, while the genitive absorbed most of the functions of the ablative.

In addition to the endings given in the tables (648-649), two other suffixes, -() and -, were sometimes used. For their uses, see 712, 715.

PARADIGMS

Nouns

, , (a, the) desire, will, plan, counsel, council. (-)[1]In the paradigms the stem of the word will be indicated each time in parentheses; it will not be accented, and will be followed by a dash, as (-) above.

  • N. (a, the) plan (as subject).
  • G. of; off, from (a, the) plan.
  • D. to, for; with, by; in, at, on (a, the) plan.
  • A. (a, the) plan (as object).
  • V. O plan!

    DUAL

  • G. D. of; off, from; to, for; with, by; in, at, on (the) two plans.

    PLURAL

  • N. V. (the) plans (as subject); O plans!
  • G. [, -] of; off, from (the) plans.
  • D. , to, for; with, by; in, at, on (the) plans.
  • A. (the) plans (as object).

Use of Article

Observe that there are no words used regularly in Homeric Greek with the meaning of the English article, either definite (the) or indefinite (a, an). One decides from the context whether or not the English article is to be employed in translation.

Meanings of Cases

The variety of meaning found in the genitive and dative is due to the fact that each represents the fusion of two or more earlier cases (657). An attempt is made to represent this above by the use of semicolons to separate meanings which once belonged to different cases.

(a, the) good plan. (- -)

    SINGULAR

  • N. (a, the) good plan (as subject).
  • G. of; off, from (a, the) good plan.
  • D. to, for; with, by; in, at, on (a, the) good plan.
  • A. (a, the) good plan (as object).
  • V. O good plan!

    DUAL

  • N. A. V. (the) two good plans (as subject, or object); O two good plans!
  • G. D. of; off, from; to, for; with, by; in, at, on (the) two good plans.

    PLURAL

  • N. V. (the) good plans (as subject); O good plans!
  • G. [, ] of; off, from (the) good plans.
  • D. , to, for; with, by; in, at, on (the) good plans.
  • A. (the) good plans (as object).

Observe that the original of the stem of first declension nouns commonly becomes throughout the singular (621). It rarely remains (in goddess, and a few proper names).

[pg. 235]

NOUNS, SECOND DECLENSION

In some feminines the of the stem becomes in the nominative, which is found also in the accusative and vocative, but in the genitive and dative singular the of the stem becomes , just as in nouns ending in in the nominative singular.

The masculines usually take the case-ending - in the nominative singular; the feminines do not.

The nominative singular of a few masculines ends in -; a very few end in -s, but most end in -. Those ending in -, excepting those with variant forms in -, regularly have the recessive accent (548), and all are adjectival except the proper name Thyestes.

Masculines and feminines of the first declension are all declined alike in the dual and plural.

Masculines ending in - and -s in the nominative singular retain this or throughout the singular, with the exception that the genitive singular always has either the ending -o (regular) or - (rare).

Those ending in - in the nominative have the same form also in the vocative singular, but otherwise are declined like those ending in -.

Feminines ending in - or - in the nominative singular retain this throughout the singular.

Those ending in - retain this only in the nominative, accusative, and vocative: the genitive and dative are declined the same as those ending in -.

Masculines are declined like feminines except in the nominative and genitive singular, and occasionally in the vocative singular.

Masculines ending in - have - in the vocative singular; those ending in - [-], compound nouns, and names of nationalities have -; those ending in -as have -a.

THE SECOND DECLENSION

Nouns of the second declension have stems ending in - (- in the voc. sing. m. and f., which stands in ablaut relation (593-595) to the -). They are chiefly masculine and neuter, with a very few feminines.

[pg. 236]

The masculines and feminines end in - in the nominative singular, the neuters in -. These when combined with - of the stem give the endings - for the masculines and feminines and - for neuters. The masculines and feminines are declined alike; the neuters differ from them in two respects:

  • The nominative, accusative, and vocative singular all end in - (i.e. -).
  • The nominative, accusative, and vocative plural end in -.

    , , (-)
  • spirit, life, soul.

SINGULAR

.G., []D..V.

DUAL

. . V.G. D.

PLURAL

. V.G.D., .

[pg. 237]
, , noble deed. (- -) , , evil war. (- -) , , destructive plague. (- -)

.

THE THIRD DECLENSION

Nouns of the third declension are masculine, feminine, and neuter.

There are many forms of the nominative of third declension nouns, which must be learned partly by practice, but in general:

  • Masculine and feminine stems, except those ending in , , and , add to the stem and make the usual euphonic changes (613).
  • Masculine and feminine stems ending in , and most of those ending in make no change except to lengthen the last vowel if it is short, becoming and becoming .
  • Stems ending in () either make no change except to lengthen the last vowel if it is short, dropping final - wherever it occurs, or else they add to the stem and make the usual euphonic changes (613), loss of () and lengthening of the preceding vowel. Thus the stems: -, -, -, - give the nominatives divinity, shore, beach, black and old man, respectively.

In neuters the nominative singular is usually the stem, with the exception of those with stems ending in , which is dropped wherever it occurs (605).

As a rule the stem of third declension nouns may be found by dropping the case ending (-) of the genitive singular.

The dative singular regularly ends in , but occasionally in .

The accusative singular of masculine and feminine nouns is regularly formed by adding to stems ending in vowels and by adding (597) to consonantal stems. of course regularly becomes - (598, 4), thus making the case ending of accusatives singular masculine and feminine regularly - for vowel stems and - for consonantal stems.

[pg. 238]

The dative plural is formed in two ways:

  • By adding - (rarely -) to the stem.
  • By adding - (rarely -) to the stem.

NOTE. When - [-] is added, the preceding consonants are assimilated, or dropped, according to the rules (613 ff.). Thus , , foot gives - (from -), which may be further simplified to ; , , night gives (from -); , , old man, gives (from -), etc. The longer forms of the datives of these nouns are , , .

The accusative plural of masculines and feminines originally ended in - (-), which gives the ending - (598, 4) for consonant stems, and -, -s (613 ff.) as the regular ending for the vowel stems.

NOTE. A few vowel stems seem to have had -as in the accusative plural, formed by analogy from the consonantal stems.

Words ending in - and - in the nominative singular, but with dental mute (, , ) stems very rarely drop the mute and take the accusative singular ending (-) of vowel stems.

The vocative singular is either the same as the nominative, or else the same as the stem, final consonants except , , (605) being dropped whenever they occur.

Compensative lengthening (601) regularly takes place in the formation of the dative plural when is thus dropped, but does not take place when only one letter, as , , , , , is dropped; as (-), (-), (-).

DENTAL MUTE STEMS

    , , (-)
  • king, lord
    • , , (-)

    • , , , (-)

    • , , (-)
  • old man

A.

Observe the irregular accent of (642), genitive plural of . This word is somewhat irregular, owing to the fact that it was earlier dissyllabic (). It has the following variants of accent: nom. sing. , ; voc. sing. , .

LABIAL AND PALATAL STEMS

Observe that stems ending in lose this when it comes between two vowels (603). Thus these words were formerly declined:

SINGULAR

 = (621) = (602). = = G. = = D.

and thus throughout the whole declension, all numbers. The loss of intervocalic (603-604), and of F also from (602), gave the forms found above, 707.

Observe that all nouns ending in - in the nominative singular are masculine or feminine (almost always masculine) if of the second declension, and that they are neuter if of the third declension.

Nouns ending in -, in the nominative singular, and all others with genitives in - are neuter.

[pg. 244]

STRAY CASE FORMS

The old ending - may be added to the stem of a noun or a pronoun to indicate place where.

The ending - may be added to the stem of a noun or a pronoun to indicate source or separation, or to express various other relations of the genitive, as from heaven, of you.

-, a postpositive (15, 3) enclitic (553; 554, 6), with the force of a preposition (, , ), may be added to the accusative to denote place to which, or limit of motion, as to the assembly.

The ending - may be added to the stem of a noun to denote place where, or in which (the locative, 657), as at home.

The ending -(), added to the stem of a noun or pronoun, is used to express various relations, both singular and plural, of both genitive and dative (especially when used in the instrumental sense).

Irregular Nouns. There are various types of irregularity in the formation and declension of nouns; the gender in the plural may be different from that in the singular; words may be declined from two separate stems (heteroclites), but have the same nominative singular; they may have cases formed from another stem than the nominative singular (metaplastic forms); or they may be used in only one case, or part of the cases (defectives). Irregular nouns can best be learned from the lexicon, as one meets them in reading and has occasion to use them. Most of them are very rare.

Adjectives

Adjectives have three declensions, as nouns, and follow the same general rules.

With respect to form they may be divided into four classes:

  • Adjectives of the first and second (vowel) declensions.
  • Adjectives of the second declension (mostly compounds).
  • Adjectives of the first and third declensions.
  • Adjectives of the third (consonant) declension.

[pg. 245]

The form of the adjective which appears in the vocabulary is the nominative singular of all genders (except in the case of a very few of only one gender, in which case the nominative and genitive singular are given).

Adjectives of the first and second declensions have three endings (, , ) in the nominative singular, for the three genders, masculine, feminine, and neuter, respectively.

ADJECTIVES OF THE FIRST AND SECOND DECLENSIONS

The feminine of adjectives of the first and second declensions regularly ends in -, and is declined as above; a few end in the -, as , a, ov, and are declined as (663).

Adjectives of the second declension have only two endings (, ), of which the first is both masculine and feminine, the second neuter. Most of these adjectives are compounds.

The masculine form of many adjectives is often used for both masculine and feminine, even in the case of those which have separate forms for the feminine.

Adjectives of the first and third declensions have a separate form for the feminine, which is declined like a noun in -a (, 663) of the first declension.

The masculine and neuter of adjectives with stems in --, -F- are declined like and respectively (704).

Declension of Participles

All middle and passive participles, except those of the first and second aorist passive, are declined like , , (721).

All active participles (except the perfect, 744) and both first and second aorist passive participles have stems in -. The masculine and neuter are of the third declension, the feminine of the first.

The vocative of participles has the same form as the nominative.

Participles with stems in usually have the nominative singular masculine in -, as 693.

But the present and second aorist of - verbs (, ), and all stems ending in , , , add , lose (613), and lengthen the preceding vowel (giving , , , 601). The dative plural of these stems is similarly formed.

Participles with stems in , ending in -, , in the nominative singular:

, , loosing, freeing (-, -, -)

Perfect Active Participles

Perfect active participles have stems in (). Those which have are called first perfects, those without second perfects.

NOTE 1.

, , does not occur in Homer, and there are very few first perfects in Homeric Greek. The forms of the first perfect participle, as given above are common in later Greek.

NOTE 2. - Perfect participles are often declined with instead of throughout; and at times end in -, -, -ov and are inflected with the same endings as the present participle.

Participles of contract verbs, 936-944 (usually left uncontracted) are declined in their contracted forms as follows:

, , (, , ) honoring (-, -, -)

The participles of - contract verbs (as anger) end in -, , (as , , ) in the nominative singular, and are quite regular in their declension, the genitive being , , ; the dative being , , , etc.

Comparison of Adjectives

Most adjectives form their comparatives by adding -, , , and their superlatives by adding -, , to the stem of the masculine positive.

If the penult of the stem is long by nature or position (522), the stem for the comparative and superlative remains unchanged. If it is short, it is regularly lengthened, becoming .

EXAMPLES

PositiveComparativeSuperlative (-) faithful, trustworthy (-) soft, gentle

The declension of comparatives and superlatives is usually the regular vowel declension of adjectives, as , , (721).

[pg. 256]

Some adjectives, mainly those in - and -, form the comparative and superlative by changing these endings to -, - for the comparative, and to -, , for the superlative.

EXAMPLES

PositiveComparativeSuperlative sweet, sweeter, , sweetest shameful, more shameful, , most shameful

The comparative of these adjectives is declined like , (731), and the superlative like , , (721).

The most important cases of irregular comparison are:

PositiveComparativeSuperlative 1) good, brave, noble, , , , , (, , ), , 2) (, , ) , , () powerful, () ()3) , , bad, cowardly, () , , () (, ), , , , 4) , , beautiful, noble, , , 5) large, mighty, (, ?), , 6) small, tiny, 7) small, tiny, , , 8) small, few, (, ), , 9) much, many, (, ), , 10) dear, lovely, , (, ), ,

Some adjectives do not occur in the positive. Their comparatives and superlatives are formed from prepositions, adverbs, verbs, nouns, and pronouns.

[pg. 257]

The comparative and superlative may express merely a high degree of the quality, without any idea of comparison being involved, and at times may indicate simply characteristic or possession.

Numerals

The Greek numerals were as follows:

Personal Pronouns

The personal pronouns are declined as follows:

SINGULAR() I [] youhe, she, it . V.() []G., (, , ), (, , , ), , (, , , , )D., , [], ()., , , (, )
[*]1 = , 584, 2. [pg. 259] DUAL N. A. V., , G. D. ()
PLURAL . V. () ()G. () (), (, )D. ((), , ) ((), ), (())A. (, , ) (), (),

The nominative singular of the personal pronouns is used only for the sake of emphasis and contrast, being omitted under other conditions.

The oblique cases of these pronouns are enclitic (553), but if the pronoun is emphatic these cases keep their accent, and the longer forms of the first person are then used. This happens as a rule after prepositions. The forms without accent in the above table are enclitic.

The pronoun of the third person is sometimes used as a reflexive, that is, it refers to the subject of the leading verb of the sentence.

The possessive pronouns are formed from the stems of the personal pronouns and are declined like adjectives of the vowel declension, i.e. like , , (721).

Possessive Pronouns

SING., , my, mine., , (, , ) your(s)., , (, , ) his, her(s), its (own), [my, your own].DUAL., , our(s)., , your(s).PLURAL., , our(s). , , our(s)., , your(s). , , your(s)., , their(s). , , their(s).

The most common pronoun, , , , used regularly as the definite article in later Greek, is usually employed as the demonstrative, but sometimes as a personal or as a relative pronoun in Homer. It is declined as follows:

, , this, that; he, she, it; who, which, what

SINGULARMASC.FEM.NEUT..G., , D..[pg. 260]DUAL. .()G. D.()PLURAL. () ()G. []D., , , .

The intensive pronoun is declined as follows:

, , self, same

SINGULARMASC.FEM.NEUT..G., , D..DUAL. .()G. D.()PLURAL.G. [, ]D., , , .

The most important interrogative pronoun, , who? which? what? has the acute accent always on the first syllable, and never changes the acute to the grave, even when followed by other words.

[pg. 261]

The indefinite , some (one), any (one), something, anything, a(n) is spelled and declined the same as the interrogative, but differs from it in accent, the indefinite pronoun being always an enclitic, 553 ff.

Indefinite and Interrogative Pronouns , some (one), any (one), something , , who? which? what?

SINGULARSINGULARMASC. AND FEM.NEUT.MASC. AND FEM.NEUT..G. () ()D. (, ) (, ).DUALDUAL. .G. D.PLURALPLURAL. ()G.D.. ()

The relative pronouns are , , , and , , who, which, what (765), together with the indefinite relative pronoun , , ( , , ) whoever, whichever, whatever, 776.

The most important demonstrative pronouns are , , this, (), , that, , , (used also as a relative and as a personal pronoun, 765) this, that, with its compounds, as , , ; , , ( , , ), etc.

These pronouns are declined in the main like adjectives of the vowel declension (, , , 721) with the exception that the neuter nominative and accusative singular ends in - instead of in -.

[pg. 262]

NOTE. - The dative plural of , , at times has () instead of ().

Compounds of , , (as , , ; , , ) are declined the same as the simple form (, , ) with the additional part (-, , etc.) attached. As these are compounds, formed of the simple pronouns and the enclitics, they are accented the same as the simple forms without the enclitics (553, 558).

The indefinite relative pronoun (, , ) whoever, whichever, whatever, is a compound of the simple relative (, , ) and the indefinite , , each part of which is declined separately (or sometimes only the latter part).

[pg. 264]

, the neuter of the indefinite relative pronoun, is thus printed in most texts, that it may not be confused with the conjunction, that, because, why.

The Reciprocal Pronoun , , (of) one another

DUALMASC.FEM.NEUT.G.D..PLURALG. [, ]D.()()().

This pronoun is used only in the genitive, dative, and accusative.

Adverbs

Most Greek adverbs are of twofold origin:

  • 1) Isolated case-forms of nouns, pronouns, and adjectives, which became crystallized and used in an adverbial connection.
  • 2) Adverbs formed by means of various suffixes (630), of which the origin is unknown.

The most common occurrence of the use of various cases of the noun, pronoun, and adjective adverbially is the employment of the neuter accusative of the adjective, singular or plural, with or without the pronoun , , as an adverb. The neuter of nouns and pronouns is sometimes, but less commonly, used in the same way.

A great number of adverbs end either in - or in -.

Those ending in - are adverbs of manner, and are formed from adjectives and pronouns. They have the accent of the genitive plural neuter of the word from which they are formed.

[pg. 264] FIGURES FROM THE PEDIMENT OF THE PARTHENON GROUPS FROM THE PARTHENON FRIEZE CORNER OF THE PARTHENON (RESTORED) CARYATID PORCH OF THE ERECHTHEUM [pg. 265]

For the comparative of these adverbs, the neuter accusative singular of the comparative of the adjective is used, and for the superlative the neuter accusative plural of the superlative of the adjective.

Adverbs of place which end in - (and a few others) form the comparative by adding -, and the superlative by adding - to the stem (630).

The prepositions were originally adverbs, and most of them are still so used in Homer.

EXAMPLES OF FORMATION

ADJECTIVESTEMGENITIVE PLURALADVERB , , -, , -, , -

The most important suffixes (630) used in the formation of adverbs (780, 2) are:

  • 1) -, -, -, -, denoting place where.
  • 2) -, -(), denoting place where.
  • 3) -, denoting place whence.
  • 4) - (originally an enclitic preposition = English to), denoting whither.
  • 5) -, denoting whither.
  • 6) -, denoting time.
  • 7) -, denoting where.
  • 8) - (origin unknown), as in -.
  • 9) - (origin unknown), as in -.
  • 10) - (with generalizing, indefinite meaning; akin to , ), as - many a time, often.
  • 11) Some other endings are -a, -, -, -, -.

Verbs

[pg. 265]

Verbs, as well as all other inflected (626-630) forms, consist of two principal elements:

  • 1) the stem;
  • 2) the ending, or suffix.
[pg. 266]

Often more than one suffix is fused with a verb stem, to indicate its various relations of mode, tense, voice, person, number, etc., as , -- (from loose), where the primary stem of the verb is -, to which the suffixes are attached.

The forms of a Greek verb fall into two main classes:

  • 1) Finite (indicative, subjunctive, optative, and imperative).
  • 2) Infinite (infinitive and participle).

The characteristics of the finite forms are the personal endings, augment, reduplication, voice, mode, and tense signs, etc.

The participle is a verbal adjective, and is used as other adjectives.

The infinitive is a verbal noun, formerly used in several cases, but restricted in Greek to old case-forms of the dative and locative.

Thematic and Athematic forms. With respect to form Greek verbs fall into two main classes:

  • 1) - verbs, i.e. those ending in - in the first person singular, present active indicative, sometimes called thematic verbs (796).
  • 2) - verbs, i.e. those ending in - in the first person singular, present active indicative, sometimes called athematic verbs (797).

The thematic verbs are so named because in a majority of their forms the personal ending (819-821) is preceded by / ( before or , or in the optative mode, otherwise ), which is called the thematic vowel. Thus, / () is called the theme, to which the personal endings (819-821) are attached.

Athematic verbs do not have this connecting vowel, but the personal endings are attached directly to the stem of the verb.

Many verbs which are regularly thematic may have athematic forms, as , (); , (); (), etc.

In the subjunctive these thematic vowels, /, are regularly long, being / respectively.

In some cases the thematic vowel is short in the subjunctive, particularly in the dual and plural of the present and second aorist of - verbs, the first aorist and second perfect of all verbs, and the second aorist of all verbs having athematic second aorists in the indicative.

[pg. 267]

Strictly speaking no Greek verb is thematic or athematic throughout; but certain of their forms are inflected thematically and others athematically.

Those inflected thematically are: all futures; all presents and imperfects of - verbs (thematic presents); all second aorists having the thematic vowel (ending in - in the first person singular, active indicative, 865); all subjunctives.

The athematic forms are: the presents and imperfects in all voices of - (athematic) verbs; all aorists passive (except the subjunctive forms); all middle and passive perfects and pluperfects; all second aorists whose tense stem does not end in the thematic vowel (796); a few verbs (as ) in the second perfect and pluperfect, active; all first aorists, active and middle. The perfects and pluperfects active are primarily athematic in their inflection.

In the thematic inflection the tense stem varies, /, as indicated above.

In the athematic inflection the final vowel of the tense stem is usually long (lengthened grade) in the singular, and commonly (but not always) is short (standing in ablaut relation (593-595), weakened or disappearing grade) in the dual and plural. This is particularly true of athematic presents and imperfects, second aorists, perfects, and pluperfects active.

Voices and Modes. The Greek verb has three voices: active, middle, and passive. Each voice has six modes: the indicative, subjunctive, optative, imperative, infinitive, and participial.

Tense systems. The Greek verb has the following nine systems of tenses:

  • 1) present, consisting of the present and imperfect.
  • 2) future, consisting of the future, active and middle.
  • 3) first aorist, consisting of the first aorist, active and middle.
  • 4) second aorist, consisting of the second aorist, active and middle.
  • 5) first perfect, consisting of the first perfect and pluperfect active.
  • 6) second perfect, consisting of the second perfect and pluperfect active.
  • 7) perfect middle, consisting of the perfect, pluperfect, and future perfect middle (passive).
  • 8) first passive, consisting of the first aorist passive.
  • 9) second passive, consisting of the second aorist passive.
[pg. 268]

Each of these systems has a stem, called the tense stem, to which are added certain endings to denote person and number.

Tense Suffixes. The suffixes (630) by which the various tense stems are formed from the verb stem are as follows:

  • 1) present:
    • a) thematic / ( before or , or in the optative, otherwise ), as -, --;
    • b) athematic none, as -, -.
  • 2) future:
    • a) ()/ (same rule as the present for /; after long vowels or diphthongs; either or after short vowels), as --, --.
    • b) / in liquid and nasal stems (514-516), and regularly dropped (603), as --, --; exceptions -, -, -.
  • 3) first aorist:
    • a) () ( after long vowels or diphthongs; either or after short vowels).
    • b) / in a few cases.
    • c) is usually lost in liquid and nasal verbs, and the preceding vowel lengthened by compensation (601), as --, --, for , .
    Exceptions to c): --, --, -.
  • 4) second aorist:
    • a) thematic /, as ---, ---.
    • b) athematic none, as --, --, --, -.
  • 5) first perfect , pluperfect , as --, ---- (-).
  • 6) second perfect , pluperfect , as --, ---- (-), or none, as --, --.
  • 7) perfect middle none, as --; future perfect ()/.
  • 8) first passive /, as ---, ---.
  • 9) second passive /, as ---, ---.
[pg. 269]

Principal Parts. The principal parts of a verb are the first person singular of each tense system found in it.

No verb has all the tense systems entire. Most verbs have no more than six: the present, future, first aorist, first (or second) perfect active, perfect middle (passive), and the first or second aorist passive. If the verb does not have a future active, the future middle (passive) is given. If the verb has a second aorist, it is added.

Of deponent verbs (897) the principal parts are: the present, future, perfect, and aorist. This includes both first and second aorists, middle and passive, if they occur.

Mode Suffix. Observe that the optative has also the mode suffix /, which contracts with the final vowel of the tense stem, as for ---, for ---.

Tenses. Of the tenses, seven are found in the indicative mode: the present, imperfect, aorist, future, perfect, pluperfect, and future perfect.

The other modes have the present, aorist, and perfect tenses; the infinitive and participle have in addition the future tense.

The tenses of the indicative are distinguished as:

  • 1) principal (primary) tenses: the present, future, perfect, and future perfect.
  • 2) past (secondary) tenses: imperfect, aorist, and pluperfect (historical tenses).

The passive has a distinct form only in the aorist;[*]Two second future forms (, ) are found. in the other tenses the middle form has both the middle and passive meaning.

Number and Person. There are three numbers (singular, dual, plural) of the Greek verb, as in nouns, and three persons (first, second, third).

Endings. Certain suffixes, called personal endings, are attached to the tense stems of the various finite (791) modes, and other endings are attached to the infinitives and participles, to make the complete verbal forms.

[pg. 270]

Some of these personal endings have undergone considerable changes.

In their earlier form they were as follows:

ACTIVE

3 - = - 3 -()

2 - 2 -
3 - 3 -
PLURAL 1 - 1 -
2 - 2 -
3 - = - 3 -(), -

2 - 2 -

3 - -
