3 - -

Observe that the subjunctive has the same endings throughout as the primary tenses of the indicative, while the optative (except at times in the first singular, when it ends in -), has the same endings as the secondary tenses of the indicative.

[pg. 271]

The first and second aorists passive have the same endings as the secondary tenses of the active voice.

PRIMARY ENDINGS OF THE ACTIVE VOICE (INDICATIVE AND SUBJUNCTIVE)

1 sing.: - is found in the present indicative of all - verbs, and in a few subjunctives of - verbs. - is found in the present indicative of all - verbs, in all futures, and in the subjunctive. In the perfect indicative there is no personal ending, - taking the place of the thematic vowel.

2 sing.: - is found only in you are; elsewhere - has taken its place. - (-) is used at times in the perfect, imperfect and pluperfect of the indicative, and occasionally in the subjunctive and optative.

3 sing.: - is found only in he is. It becomes - in the other - verbs, and - is occasionally found in the subjunctive of - verbs. - verbs have another ending, -, of which the origin is uncertain. The perfect, -, has no personal ending.

3 plur.: - regularly becomes -, and is then lost, with lengthening of the preceding vowel (613). Many - verbs seem to have ended in -, which first became -, and then - (613). The perfect of consonant stems ended in - (-) which became - (-) and then - (597-8). Generally - in both present and perfect has been replaced by -.

SECONDARY ENDINGS OF THE ACTIVE (INDICATIVE AND OPTATIVE)

1 sing.: - after vowels remained unchanged; after consonants it became -, and then - (597-8). Pluperfect - is usually contracted to -. The optative has - when the mode suffix is -- (813); otherwise it has -.

3 sing.: - is always dropped (605); from ; cf. amat, has no personal ending; it takes its - from the perfect.

2 dual: - sometimes occurs instead of -.

3 dual: - sometimes occurs instead of -.

[pg. 272]

3 plur.: - is for an earlier -, being lost (605), the vowel before it being regularly short. -, from the first aorist ending, is used in the imperfect, and often in the second aorist of - verbs, at times in the aorist passive, in the pluperfect active, and in the optative when it has the mode suffix --.

MIDDLE ENDINGS, PRIMARY AND SECONDARY (INDICATIVE, SUBJUNCTIVE, AND OPTATIVE)

2 sing.: - drops its between vowels (603), except in the perfect, and in the present indicative of - verbs.

2 sing. (secondary): - regularly drops its between vowels (603), except in the pluperfect, and in the imperfect of - verbs. In a few cases is dropped in the pluperfect.

Dual: the first dual - is rare; - occurs once instead of -.

3 plur.: -, - regularly become -, - (-, -) in the perfect and pluperfect of verbs with consonant stems, stems ending in -, occasionally in vowel stems, and always in the optative. Elsewhere occasionally -, - become -, - (597-8).

ENDINGS OF THE IMPERATIVE

2 sing. active: - of the second sing. is the thematic vowel, and forms like , have no personal ending. - is common, with both an active and passive meaning. In the first aorist passive - becomes - after -- of the passive stem (619). - occurs in a few cases. The endings of the aorist, - (active) and - (middle) are obscure.

2 sing. middle: - loses its between vowels (603), except in the perfect of all verbs and the pres. of - verbs.

ENDINGS OF THE INFINITIVES, PARTICIPLES, AND VERBAL ADJECTIVES

Infinitives have the following endings:

  • 1) dative (794): - (-, -, -, - active; and -, - middle and passive).
    • [pg. 273]
  • 2) locative (794): -, - (following the thematic vowel , - regularly contracts to -, 584-5).

Participles have the following endings added to the tense stem:

  • 1) -- for all active tenses, except the perfect (usually), and the first and second aorists passive.
  • 2) -- (--), occasionally -- in the perfect active.
  • 3) -- (feminine --) in the middle; and in the passive, except the aorist passive.
[*]Verbal adjectives end in -, and are usually equivalent to passive (sometimes active) participles in meaning, or else denote possibility, as [] known, [] made, [] made. They are formed by adding the ending to the verb stem, usually as it appears in the first or second aorist passive.

Augment

Greek verbs prefix an augment (increase) at the beginning of the secondary (816) tenses of the indicative, to denote past time.

This augment is of two kinds:

  • 1) syllabic augment, which prefixes - to verbs beginning with a consonant, as I loose, imperfect I was loosing.
  • 2) temporal augment, which lengthens the first syllable of words beginning with a vowel or a diphthong, as I hear, I was hearing.

When augmented , regularly become ; , , become , , respectively; and become and ; while becomes .

Of course , , , , , and do not undergo any change when augmented.

Verbs beginning with regularly double it after the augment. Those beginning with , , , or sometimes double the initial consonant after the augment.

Verbs beginning with a vowel formerly preceded by a lost consonant (usually , or ), may take the syllabic instead of the temporal augment, as , imperfect of () please.

When initial has thus been lost, the augment always contracts with the first vowel of the stem, according to the rules (584-5); when initial has been lost, contraction may or may not take place. Thus (), imperfect (, ); (), imperfect (, ); (), second aorist of (); (), aorist ().

[pg. 274]

The augment, both syllabic and temporal, is often omitted.

Compound Verbs. Some prepositions (originally adverbs) are prefixed to verbs, the whole forming a compound. If the preposition ends with a vowel and the verb begins with one, the vowel of the preposition is usually elided (575), as (-), (- (582)).

The augment of compound verbs comes between the preposition and the verb. If two vowels are thus brought together, the first is usually elided, as loose, free; imperfect (-); aorist (-).

Imperfect. The imperfect (a secondary tense (816)) is formed by adding the secondary endings (821) to the augmented stem of the present, as I loose, imperfect I was loosing; I place, imperfect .

First Aorist. The first aorist of vowel and mute verbs (849) (a secondary tense, 816) is regularly formed by adding -() to the augmented verb stem, followed by the personal endings of the secondary tenses. If the verb stem ends in a long vowel or a consonant only one is ever added; if it ends in a short vowel, either one or two sigmas may be used.

"Mixed" Aorists. A few aorists (sometimes called "mixed aorists") are formed by adding -/, followed by the personal endings of the secondary tenses, to the augmented verb stem.

throw, send; give, grant; and put, place, have - in the aorist instead of -.

Future. The future (a primary tense) of vowel and mute verbs (849) is regularly formed by adding the tense suffix -()/ to the verb stem, followed by the personal endings of the primary tenses.

[pg. 275]

If the verb stem ends in a long vowel, the stem is not affected by the addition of -/ and - in the formation of the future and aorist.

If the verb stem ends in a short vowel, all tenses except the present and imperfect regularly lengthen this, and becoming ; becoming ; as , , ; , , . Exception: gives , .

Some verbs do not lengthen the short vowel according to the rule in 846.

These, and a few others, usually have before the personal ending of the perfect middle and the aorist passive.

Classes of Verbs

Verbs are called vowel verbs, liquid verbs, nasal verbs, and mute verbs, according as their stem ends in a vowel, a liquid, a nasal, or a mute (509-516).

Mute Verbs. If the verb stem ends in a mute, the following euphonic changes take place:

  • 1) a labial mute (, , ) unites with the sigma following and forms , as , (), () send, escort: , , (, ) (ex)change;
  • 2) a palatal mute (, , ) unites with the sigma following and forms , as , (), () help, assist; , (), () make, fashion, cause.
  • 3) a lingual mute (, , ) before the is assimilated (610, 4), as , , persuade; , , sing.

Liquid and Nasal Verbs. If a verb stem ends in a liquid (, ) or a nasal (, ), the future is regularly formed by adding -/, with the loss of between vowels (603), to the verb stem, to which are attached the primary personal endings, as , (from ) throw, shoot.

In a few cases the first is omitted, and is retained in verbs of this kind, as , arouse, stir up.

A few verbs in addition to those with liquid and nasal stems have lost in the future, as , call, summon. In general these verbs have a liquid or nasal before the final vowel of the stem, and imitate the forms of the futures of liquid and nasal verbs.

[pg. 276]

Those formations in which is dropped after or are sometimes called "Attic futures."

A few verbs have active forms in the present, but middle forms in the future, as , hear.

Verbs with liquid and nasal stems regularly form their aorists by dropping the and lengthening the stem vowel by compensation (601), becoming , becoming , becoming , and becoming , as (-), (), () show; , (), () remain, await.

In some cases the is retained in formations of this kind, as , stir up, arouse; , land; , meet.

The present of most liquid and nasal verbs regularly lengthens the last syllable of the stem by compensation (601) as the original form of the stem of these verbs ended in consonantal (600).

Presents in - are from an earlier form in -. Thus , , , , etc., were originally , , , , etc. In these cases the last syllable of the stem is lengthened by doubling the final .

Verbs with presents in -, -, -, -, -, -, -, - originally had the endings -, -, -, -, -, -, -, - (consonantal , 600) respectively.

The quantity of the last vowel of the stem of many verbs often varies, as , , , *, , .

Ablaut (vowel gradation, 593-595) is seen in the various tense systems of many verbs, particularly in what are known as "second" (863) tenses. The second aorist and second passive systems commonly have the weak (594-595) grades , , . The other systems usually have the corresponding strong grades (), (), (); , , in the second perfect. When is preceded or followed by a liquid or a nasal its weak grade is .

[pg. 277]

Second Tenses. Many verbs have what are called second tenses, as second aorists (active, middle, and passive), and second perfects and pluperfects (active). These second tenses are irregular in formation, and are thus named to distinguish them from the more common, regularly formed tenses, which are called first tenses.

The meaning of these second tenses ordinarily corresponds to that of the first tenses, except in the comparatively few cases when a verb has both forms. Then the first and second tenses may differ slightly in meaning, usually by the first being transitive (sometimes causative), the second intransitive. Compare the Americanism shine, shined, shined, used transitively, as in the expression "he shined my shoes," with the more common forms of the verb, shine, shone, shone, used intransitively, as "the sun shone." "Shined" may be compared in form and meaning to a first aorist, while "shone" would correspond in form and meaning to a second aorist. Thus in Greek, (2d aor.) signifies I went, walked (intransitive), while (1st aor.) signifies I caused to go, walked (transitive), as in English I walked my horse ( ) i.e. I caused my horse to walk.

Second aorists are formed in various ways:

  • 1) A common method is for them to have the secondary (816) endings, following the thematic vowel /, thus being conjugated like the imperfect, as , , to have, where the second aorist is conjugated like , the imperfect of to loose.
  • 2) Many have the secondary endings attached directly to the tense stem, and thus are conjugated like the aorist passive, but without the of the passive stem. Thus (), (), (), etc. These are athematic (797) of course.
  • 3) Others end in - and are conjugated with the same endings as the first (regular) aorists, but without the , as , .
  • 4) Many are reduplicated (867), as [], [].
[*]The stem of the second aorist usually differs from the present, regularly standing in ablaut (593-5) relation to it, as , ; , .
[pg. 278]

The stem of the singular of athematic (797, 865, 2) second aorists regularly stands in ablaut (593-5) relation to the stem found in the dual and plural.

Reduplication

The perfect and pluperfect (with a few presents, second aorists and futures) in all modes have reduplication (doubling), which regularly denotes completed (sometimes intensified) action, a state, or a condition.

Verbs beginning with a single consonant, except , prefix this consonant, followed by the letter , as , go in. Often the stem stands in ablaut (593-5) relation to the stem of the present, as (-, -), come, go.

Verbs beginning with a double consonant (518), with two consonants (except a mute followed by a liquid or nasal (509, 516), those beginning with , and some beginning with , instead of being reduplicated, simply add , the reduplication in these cases having the same form as the syllabic augment (830-1).

A rough mute when reduplicated is changed to its cognate smooth (510-511), as , ; , . This is deaspiration (dissimilation) (619).

In verbs beginning with a vowel or diphthong the reduplication has the form of the temporal (831) augment, as , .

Verbs beginning with a vowel which was formerly preceded by a lost consonant may take the reduplication in the form of the syllabic augment (830-1).

Some verbs beginning with , , or , followed by a consonant, reduplicate by repeating this vowel and the consonant and by lengthening the vowel, and becoming , and becoming , as , ; , ; , . This is sometimes called "Attic reduplication."

A few verbs reduplicate the present by prefixing the first consonant of the stem followed by , as ( 603-4), , , ( 603-4), , , , .

[pg. 279]

When the reduplicated perfect begins with a consonant, the pluperfect prefixes the syllabic augment () to the reduplication, as (perfect), (pluperfect).

In other cases the pluperfect usually retains the temporal (831) augment of the perfect unchanged.

Perfect

The first (regular) perfect adds -, the pluperfect -, to the reduplicated theme to form the singular. The dual and plural regularly have the endings of the second perfect, except at times in the third plural, which often has the endings of the first perfect.

The stem is not affected by the addition of -, -, except that a final short vowel is usually lengthened (846).

This form of the perfect (first or regular perfect) is found only in verbs with vowel stems and in only about twenty verbs in the whole of the Homeric poems.

Second Perfect

The stem of the second (irregular) perfect is formed by adding - to the reduplicated theme, and the pluperfect by adding -.

The second perfects are the earlier and are much more common in the Homeric poems than are the first or --perfects. They are found regularly in verbs with consonantal and sometimes in those with vowel stems.

The singular of the first and second perfect and pluperfect active regularly stands in ablaut (593-5) relation to the dual and plural, the dual and plural having the weak (disappearing) grade (594-5), while the singular has the strong grade.

Both perfect and pluperfect are rare in Homer, the latter occurring in only about twenty verbs.

The reduplication is occasionally omitted.

Verbs compounded with a preposition (838) regularly have the augment and the reduplication between the preposition and the verb, as , (, ).

When futures and second aorists are reduplicated it is usually after the manner of the reduplication of perfects; presents are reduplicated in various ways, but chiefly with (874).

[pg. 280]

Middle Voice

The endings of the middle are different from those of the active. See the table, 821.

Passive

The aorist passive has active endings; the other forms of the passive have middle endings.

Since only the aorist[*]But see 817, note, for two exceptions. of the passive differs in form from the middle, all the other tenses having the same forms in both voices, the context must determine in these other tenses which voice is intended.

The aorist middle, especially the athematic (797) aorist, is often used instead of the aorist passive. On the other hand the aorist passive is often used with a middle meaning.

The perfect and pluperfect, middle and passive are athematic (797), i.e. the personal endings are attached directly to the reduplicated verb stem.

The future perfect passive stem is formed by adding -/ to the perfect middle (passive) stem. A vowel which precedes this -/ is lengthened, even though it be short in the perfect middle.

The first aorist passive stem is formed by adding / to the verb stem.

Sometimes a sigma also is added to the verb stem before the /.

Before the theta of the passive stem, and become ; and become ; , , and regularly become (610, 1, 2).

Many verbs have a second aorist passive, which does not have the , but otherwise has the same endings as the first aorist passive.

Deponent Verbs

There are many verbs which have no active forms, but the middle, or the middle and passive are used with an active meaning. These are called deponent verbs.

Defective Verbs

Many verbs do not have all the principal parts, that is, they are defective. When any parts are omitted from the vocabularies of this book, it indicates that these forms do not occur either in Homer or in later classical Greek.

[pg. 281]

Periphrastic Forms

There are some forms of the verb in Greek which are expressed at times by a compound of the verb to be () with a participle of the verb. These are called periphrastic forms. The most important are:

  • 1) The perfect and pluperfect, represented at times by the perfect participle with the present and imperfect respectively of .
  • 2) The future perfect, both active and passive, represented by the future of with the perfect active and middle (passive) participle.

Iterative Forms

Many verbs have what are called iterative forms in the imperfect and aorist, active and middle. These have no augment and add followed by the personal endings to the verb stem. Some have a connecting vowel (usually , sometimes ), others do not. Thus from comes , from comes , etc.

A few verbs have special forms in the present and second aorist made by adding to the tense stem, as from (2d aor. ), from .

Accent of Verbs

Verbs, both simple and compound (838), usually have the recessive accent (548), except in the following cases:

  • 1) A few second aorists imperative, 2d singular, have the acute on the ultima, as , , , . When compounded these verbs have the recessive accent.
  • 2) The following forms accent the penult: the first aorist active infinitive, the second aorist active infinitive (usually contracted with the ultima), the second aorist middle infinitive (except , ), the perfect middle (passive) infinitives and participles, and all infinitives in - or -, except those in -.
  • 3) The following participles have the acute on the ultima for the masculine and neuter, and the circumflex on the penult of the feminine: the second aorist active, all those of the third declension (except the first aorist active) ending in - in the nominative singular masculine, and the present participles of , and (, , ).
    • [pg. 282]
  • 4) For the variations in the enclitic forms of , , see the paradigms 964, 967, and 554-556.
  • 5) The accent of athematic optatives never goes further to the left than the diphthong containing the of the mode sign.
  • 6) In unaugmented compound verbs the accent cannot go further to the left than the last syllable of the preposition with which the verb is compounded.
  • 7) Unaugmented monosyllabic second aorists have the circumflex when containing a long vowel, as (= ).
  • 8) In augmented and reduplicated compound forms the accent cannot go further back than the augment or reduplication.
  • 9) Middle imperatives in - have the acute on the penult when compounded with monosyllabic prepositions.
  • 10) The exceptions are only apparent in the accent of contracted forms 936-944, including the aorist passive subjunctive, = , and optative, -- = , the future of liquid and nasal verbs, and the present and second aorist active and middle subjunctive of most - verbs. See 951-952.

Final - and - of the optative, and the final - of the locative at home, are always considered long when determining the accent; otherwise final -, - are considered short for purposes of accent (547).

3 they have loosed they had loosed

THE SUBJUNCTIVE[1]The different tenses of the subjunctive, optative, imperative, and infinitive, do not of themselves represent distinctions of time. The present of these tenses denotes continuance of action, as (pres. infin.) to be loosing (at any time). The aorist denotes simply the occurrence of an action, its time being exactly the same as the present, as (aor. inf.) to loose (at any time). The perfect denotes completion of an action, as (perf. inf.) to have loosed (at any time).

[pg. 284]

PRESENT

AORIST
S. 1 () I may loose[2]Also let me loose, and various other meanings which must be learned from the syntax. () I may loose[2]Also let me loose, and various other meanings which must be learned from the syntax.
2 () you may loose () you may loose
3 () he may loose () he may loose
Du. 2 you two may loose you two may loose
3 they two may loose they two may loose
PL. 1 we may loose we may loose
2 you may loose you may loose
3 they may loose they may loose

PERFECT[3]Not found in Homer; see note 1, p. 283. The subjunct. and optat. perfect are very rare in Homer.

  • PRES. (, , , ) to loose, to be loosing

[pg. 286]

Middle Voice of loose

[1]The most common meanings are I loose for myself, I am loosed; I was loosing for myself, I was being loosed, etc. The context must determine which of these is most suitable. When it has an active meaning, I loose, it is with the strict implication of loosing one's own, or something in which the subject has an active personal interest, hence: to ransom, redeem, deliver, etc.

INDICATIVE

PRESENT

S. 1 I loose (for) myself, I am loosed
2 [()] you loose (for) yourself, are loosed
3 he looses (for) himself, is loosed
Du. 2 you two loose (for) yourselves, are loosed
3 they two loose (for) themselves, are loosed
PL. 1() we loose (for) ourselves, are loosed
2 you loose (for) yourselves, are loosed
3 they loose (for) themselves, are loosed

IMPERFECT

S. 1 I was loosing (for) myself, was being loosed
2 [()] you were loosing (for) yourself, were being loosed
3 he was loosing (for) himself, was being loosed
Du. 2 you two were loosing (for) yourselves, were being loosed
3 they two were loosing (for) themselves, were being loosed
PL. 1() we were loosing (for) ourselves, were being loosed
2 you were loosing (for) yourselves, were being loosed
3 they were loosing (for) themselves, were being loosed

FUTURE

INFINITIVE[1]Read the note on 905.

  • PRES. to loose (for) one's self, to be loosed
  • FUT. to loose (for) one's self, to be loosed, to be about to be loosed
  • AOR. to loose (for) one's self, to be loosed, to have loosed

  • F. PERF. to loose (for) one's self, to be loosed
[pg. 291]

PARTICIPLE

  • PRES. , , loosing (for) one's self, being loosed.
  • FUT. , , being about to loose (for) one's self, being about to be loosed, desiring to loose, ... etc.
  • AOR. , , having loosed (for) one's self, having been loosed
  • PERF. , , having loosed (for) one's self, having been loosed.
  • FUT. PERF. , , being about to have loosed (for) one's self, being about to have been loosed

Contract Verbs

Verbs which end in -, -, -; -, -, - (including the futures of liquids and nasals) in the first person singular are contracted in the present and imperfect at times. For the laws of contraction see 584-585.

Verbs in -, -, are usually contracted; those in -, -, -, -, may be, but are usually left uncontracted.

PARTICIPLE (, , ) , ,

[pg. 302]

These verbs may be contracted as indicated above, and are regularly so contracted in later classical Greek.

The manuscripts of the Homeric poems often show a series of forms for verbs ending in - (as ) and in - (as ), which are known as "assimilated" (sometimes called "distracted") forms. In these cases , , , give a double sound, by the assimilating the sound; but , , , give a double sound, by the assimilating the sound. Usually one of the vowels is lengthened, sometimes both.

= 1) 2) = 1) 2)
= 1) 2) = 1) 2)
= 1) 2) = 1) 2)
= 1) 2) = 1) 2)
= 1) 2) = 1) 2)
= 1) 2)

These forms are used also in futures in - from - (603).

They are found only when the second syllable in the original form is long by nature or by position (522).

The following forms of (-) see, may serve as examples of assimilation of an - verb:

3

The second aorist subjunctive of - verbs (949 ff.) seems to have had a double form of inflection:

  • 1) With a short thematic (796) vowel, as , , , , , , , ( put, place).
  • 2) With a long thematic (796) vowel, as , , , , , , , .

The vowel of the stem is then shortened (572), producing

3) , , , , , , , .

This form then undergoes contraction (584-585), giving

4) , , , , , , , .

The subjunctives of athematic (797; 865, 2) second aorists and the subjunctives passive of both first and second aorists are similarly formed. Thus, , , , etc., contracted from , , , etc.; , , , etc., contracted from , , , etc.

Syntax

General

[pg. 313]

III. SYNTAX

GENERAL

The subject of a finite verb is in the nominative case, as and the people kept perishing, and that old man feared.

The subject of an infinitive is regularly in the accusative, as I think we shall return home, I wish my people to be safe. The subject of the infinitive is usually omitted when it is the same as the subject or object, either direct or indirect, of the main verb.

When the infinitive is used to express a command (1107, 11), its subject, when expressed, is in the nominative when of the second person, and in the accusative when of the third person, as but do you attack him with soft words.

A finite verb regularly agrees with its subject nominative in person and number, except:

  • 1) A neuter plural subject may take its verb in the singular, as the shafts of the god sped, these have been distributed.
  • 2) With two or more subjects connected by and, the verb may agree with one of the subjects and be understood with the rest, as lest the sceptre and the fillet of the god avail thee naught, if war and pestilence at the same time crush the Achaeans.
  • 3) When referring to two, the plural and dual are often interchanged or united, as and her eyes appeared terrible, who were his two heralds and ready attendants, and let these two be witnesses.

A noun or an adjective in the predicate after verbs meaning be, appear, become, be thought, made, named, chosen, regarded, and the like, agrees with the subject in case, as and they became assembled; who boasts that he is far the mightiest of the Achaeans, but that seems (to be) even as death to you, I should be called both coward and worthless.

[pg. 314]

Apposition. A noun used in connection with another noun to describe it, and denoting the same person or thing, agrees with it in case, and is said to be in apposition with it, as the son of Atreus, king of men, he slighted Chryses, the priest.

The verb (especially the forms of the third person singular and plural , ) is often omitted, when it can easily be supplied from the context.

Other words are at times omitted, as = yea, by this sceptre (I swear).

Nouns

Nominative Case

A noun is in the nominative:

  • 1) When it is the subject of a finite verb (970).
  • 2) When it is in the predicate after certain verbs (974).
  • 3) Sometimes for the vocative, as king, who devour (the goods of) the people!

Genitive Case

The Greek genitive represents two earlier cases (657):

  • 1) the genitive proper, denoting the class to which a person or thing belongs.
  • 2) the ablatival genitive (formerly the ablative), usually expressing separation, source, cause.

Some of the most common uses of the genitive are:

  • 1) Possession, as souls of warriors, the will of Zeus, to the ships of the Achaeans: the possessive genitive.
  • 2) The subject of an action or feeling, as the wrath of Achilles (i.e. felt by Achilles): the subjective genitive.
  • 3) The object of an action or feeling, as a yearning of (i.e. for) Achilles, the desire of (i.e. for) food and drink: the objective genitive.
    • [pg. 315]
  • 4) Material or contents, as funeral pyres of corpses, hecatombs of bulls and of goats: genitive of material.
  • 5) Measure of time, space, or value (price), as to accept the ransoms for the maiden Chryses: genitive of price.
  • 6) Cause or origin, as he finds fault on account of a vow (unperformed), vexed for the sake of a woman: the genitive of cause.
  • 7) The whole after words denoting the part, as ; which (one) of the gods? the greater part of the war: the partitive genitive.

The partitive genitive may follow all adjectives, adverbs, nouns, and participles, which denote a part, as far the best of augurs, alone of the Argives, but not any one of the others saw her.

A genitive in the predicate after verbs meaning to be, etc., and other copulative verbs, may express any of the relations of the attributive genitive (979, 1-7).

Any verb whose action affects the object in part only, or which means to share, or to enjoy, may take the genitive, as having partaken of the fat of unblemished lambs and goats, in order that all may reap the benefits of their king.

Verbs meaning to begin, make trial of, take hold of, touch, attain, claim, aim, hit, miss, take the genitive, as she grabbed Achilles by the hair of his head, lay hold of his knees, having taken hold of her hand, having seized me by the foot.

Verbs signifying to taste, smell, hear, perceive, comprehend, remember, forget, desire, care for, spare, neglect, wonder at, admire, despise, take the genitive, as hear me! I reck not of thee, nor am I concerned at thine anger, she grieved for the Danaans, and they hearkened to my advice, having reminded him of this, Thetis did not forget the behests.

[pg. 316]

The genitive follows verbs signifying to rule, lead, direct, as (thou) who dost rule Tenedos, who rules all the Argives.

Verbs signifying fulness and want take the genitive of material (979, 4). Those meaning to fill take the accusative of the thing filled, and the genitive of material, as his diaphragm was filled with rage, the young men filled the mixing bowls to the brim with drink.

The genitive may denote that from which anything is separated or distinguished (genitive of separation); hence it is used after verbs meaning remove, restrain, release, cease, fail, differ, give up, etc., as cease from strife, but refrain from war. It is used also to denote source, as a terrifying clang arose from the silver bow.

The genitive follows verbs signifying surpass, be inferior to, and all others which imply a comparison (993), as I prefer (her) to Clytaemnestra, to be above all others, (you) who surpass the Danaans in counsel.

Verbs compounded with a preposition are often followed by the genitive, as (whatsoever) we took as spoil from the cities, protect your son.

The genitive may denote time within which anything takes place.

Many adjectives kindred in meaning or derivation to verbs which take the genitive are followed by the genitive (objective).

Many adverbs, chiefly those of place, and those derived from adjectives which take the genitive, are construed with the genitive, as far from her native land, in front of him, within the harbor.

Adjectives and adverbs of the comparative degree take the genitive (988), unless followed by () than, as she is not inferior to her (literally not worse than), I am mightier than you, sweeter than honey.

[pg. 317]

A noun and a participle not closely connected grammatically with the rest of the sentence may stand by themselves in the genitive. This construction is called the genitive absolute. Examples: as the god moved, while I live and look out upon the earth.

Dative Case

The Greek dative represents three earlier cases (657):

  • 1) the dative proper, denoting to or for which something is or is done.
  • 2) the instrumental (dative), denoting instrument, means, manner, cause, accompaniment.
  • 3) the locative (dative), denoting place where and time when.

The indirect object of a transitive verb is in the dative, as which Phoebus Apollo granted to him, how shall they give you a prize of honor?

Many verbs which in English are transitive are intransitive in Greek and take the dative. The verbs of this class are mainly those meaning serve, benefit, defend, assist, please, obey, trust, satisfy, advise, exhort, and their opposites; also those signifying abuse, anger, blame, envy, friendliness, hostility, reproach, threats, etc., as incensed at the king, it was not pleasing to the son of Atreus in his soul, lest the sceptre and the fillet of the god avail thee not; he obeyed the command, to defend me, when he becomes enraged at an inferior, and I shall threaten you as follows, continue to rage against the Achaeans.

A person or thing for whose advantage or disadvantage a thing exists or is done is put in the dative, as and it made themselves a booty for the dogs and a banquet for the birds, but free for me my child, accomplish for me this desire, to ward off destruction for (from) us, and you threaten to take away for (from) me my prize of honor, to forego (your) anger for Achilles, and he should throw the banquet into confusion for us.

[pg. 318]

The dative of interest or reference denotes the person to whose case a statement is limited.

The dative with , , and verbs of similar meaning, may denote the possessor, as but of all else which are mine beside my ship, who were his two heralds.

The dative of the personal pronouns often denotes the possessor, without such verbs as , , etc., as and his two eyes were like fire, my prize of honor is going elsewhere, and her eyes gleamed terribly.

The dative is used after verbs meaning to give commands, and to lead the way for, as and he led the way for the ships of the Achaeans into Troy, rule the Myrmidons.

The dative follows some verbal nouns and many adjectives and adverbs of kindred meaning with verbs which take the dative, as evil is dear to your heart, they are in no wise blamable toward me, you are most hateful to me, since he was exceeding dear to him, they will be (too) hard for you, he will be propitious toward us.

The dative is used after all words signifying likeness, or unlikeness, agreement, disagreement, union, or approach, as like unto night, and his eyes were like unto fire, never have I a prize of honor equal to you(rs), like unto the immortals.

The dative follows many verbs compounded with , , and , and some compounded with , , , and , as hurling a dart upon them, who brought sorrows upon the Argives, sitting beside the ships, she sat down beside you, Thetis devised plans with him, but I advise my mother, laughter arose among the gods.

[pg. 319]

The dative is used to denote cause, manner, means, instrument, and agency, as may the Danaans atone for my tears with thy darts, to assist with words and hands, by his deeds of arrogance he will soon lose his life, and do not continue to draw your sword with your hand, revile him with words, I will not fight with my hands, rejoicing in his glory, therefore I bore you to an evil lot, whom they took away by violence against his will, they appeased the god with music and dancing, she seized his knees with her left (hand), I shall nod assent to you with my head.

The dative is used to denote the circumstance, or that by which a thing or person is accompanied. The dative of circumstance is most common with abstract or semi-abstract words, and is often used to express the reason or occasion. we accompany you, who were bred and born with him, Hephaestus made a home for each with cunning mind, ; who brought these two together in strife?

The dative is used with verbs signifying to be with, follow, join, agree, be like, fight, strive, trust, be pleased, and occasionally with those meaning to buy and to abound, as it was not pleasing to the son of Atreus, and the Achaeans trust in him, to fight with men, they fought with the mightiest, to strive with the king, I will not fight with you.

The dative is used to denote the agent, after the past tenses, particularly the perfect and pluperfect of the passive.

The dative with or without a preposition is used to denote the place where an action takes place. It is used of towns and countries, the great divisions of the world, the chief spheres of action, of the parts of a thing, or of the human body, after some verbs that imply locality or time, and after some verbs of motion where we should expect the accusative with a preposition, as it was not pleasing in his soul, having his bow on his shoulders, and Calchas arose among them, do not play the thief in your heart, loving both (of them) in her heart, he rages in his mind, seated upon the summit, to assist the Trojans in battle, but on the tenth (day) Achilles summoned the people to an assembly, but on the twelfth (day) he will come to Olympus, and sent many souls to Hades, and do you place it in your heart, and they are taking presents to the lord, I fell into Lemnos.

[pg. 320]

The dative is used to denote in what particular point or respect something is true, as for he is better in strength than his own father. Cf. 1014.

Accusative Case

The direct object of a transitive verb is in the accusative case, as he roused a plague, he dishonored Chryses, to ransom his own daughter, bearing ransoms, having fillets, he kept entreating the Achaeans.

Any verb whose meaning permits may take an accusative of cognate form, or equivalent meaning. This is called the cognate accusative, and may follow intransitive as well as transitive verbs, as you have spoken a word, to go (on) a journey, and she spoke a word.

The words , , and with pronouns or adjectives are at times practically equivalent to the neuter of the pronoun or adjective without these words, as if I shall yield to you in every matter.

An accusative restricting the force of the verb to a part, character, quality, or attribute of the subject may follow many verbs that are intransitive or reflexive in meaning. This is the accusative of the part affected, or accusative of specification, and may also accompany a noun, an adjective, or even a whole sentence, as swift-footed Achilles (literally Achilles swift with respect to his feet), enraged in heart, , she is not inferior to her, neither in build nor beauty nor disposition, nor yet in accomplishments.

[pg. 321]

The accusative is used to denote extent of time or space, as and all day long I fell, the whole day through they feasted, he sat silent a long time.

The accusative dependent upon an omitted verb follows the adverbs of swearing , and , as by Apollo! yea, by this sceptre! (977)

The verbs and , and more often their compounds, may take an accusative of the person addressed, as he addressed Calchas, nor did they say anything to him.

The accusative may be used of the person about whom a thing is told, known, thought, or provided:

  • 1) The person or thing is treated as the thing said or known, and not merely as spoken or known about, as not even if you should say Agamemnon.
  • 2) The real object of the verb is a fact expressed by a limiting clause or word.

Words denoting the goal are in the accusative after verbs of motion, as upon whom(soever) I may come, and the savor went to heaven, go to the barrack(s) of Achilles.

The following classes of verbs may be construed with two accusatives:

  • 1) Verbs of asking, teaching, reminding, demanding, clothing, unclothing, depriving, and taking away, as Phoebus Apollo is depriving me of Chryses, nor do you deprive him of the maiden.
    • [pg. 322]
  • 2) Verbs of naming, choosing, appointing, making, thinking, regarding, and the like, as and made themselves a booty for the dogs and a banquet for the birds, , whom the gods call Briares, but all men (call) Aegaeon.
  • 3) Verbs meaning to do anything to or say anything of a person.

The accusative may denote an object which is affected by an action, and a second accusative of the particular part affected may be added (accusative of the whole and part), as ; but what grief has come upon you in your heart? the bronze has stripped it of leaves and bark round about. [*]Some would classify the accusative of this last sentence under 1020 above.

Vocative Case

The vocative, with or without , is used in addressing a person or thing, as goddess! O Achilles! sons of Atreus! [*]The nominative is often used for the vocative, 978, 3.

Adjectives

The positive of an adjective may imply that the quality indicated is not in the proper proportion for the purpose under consideration, as do not hope to know all my plans; they will be too hard for you (to understand).

The comparative and superlative endings of adjectives are often employed merely to denote an unusually high degree of the quality signified, without any idea of comparison being involved.

An adjective agrees with its noun in gender, number, and case, but not always in form, since they may belong to different declensions, as an evil plague, where , although feminine, is of the second declension and ends in -. This rule applies also to adjective pronouns and participles, as countless woes, and sent many valiant souls to Hades, these two separated after they had quarreled, godlike Achilles, he came to the swift ships, the gods who have Olympian homes.

[pg. 323]

When referring to two, the plural and the dual are freely interchanged (973, 3), as two generations, and these two themselves be witnesses.

An adjective or a participle, usually with the pronoun , , , may be used substantively as a noun, as both what is, what will be, and what has been before, these calamities, such calamities (1034).

Pronouns

The Pronoun , ,

There are three chief uses of the pronoun, , , :

  • 1) As an independent demonstrative (and third personal) pronoun, meaning this, that, he, she, it. This is its original use, and the one most commonly met with in Homer, as he roused a plague, the son of Atreus dishonored that (well-known) Chryses, the priest, but I will not free her, and that old man feared.
  • 2) As an article properly speaking ("the"), that is, modifying and making definite a noun, but not having any particular demonstrative force. This is its ordinary use in Greek after Homer.
  • 3) As a relative pronoun, as whom Leto bore, who were his two heralds, whom the sons of the Achaeans gave unto me.
[*]Many expressions in Homer which are translated into English by the relative pronoun in a subordinate clause seem to have been cordinate originally. Thus the pronoun (, , ) in these last three sentences may well have been thought of as demonstrative with asyndeton rather than as relative, 11131114.

As an independent pronoun it has two main uses:

  • 1) It is "resumptive," that is, it refers to something already mentioned, , he dishonored Chryses, for he came to the swift ships.
    • [pg. 324]
  • 2) It makes a contrast, usually in combinations, such as ... , and other words which help to give this effect.

... and ... are frequently used to contrast both definite and indefinite persons and things.

Its use with an adversative particle generally, but not always, marks a change of subject, as but the other.

The use of , , as an article has evidently arisen from its employment as an independent pronoun, followed by a noun in apposition, as but she went with them against her will, i.e. the woman, where is added as an afterthought for the sake of greater definiteness.

So also it may serve to introduce a new person, in this case anticipating the noun, as but he kept raging as he sat beside the ships, did the Zeus-born son of Peleus, the swift-footed Achilles.

With the adjective or participle it is often used as a substantive, as the greater part, these calamities, such calamities (1027).

It is also used with the neuter accusative, singular or plural, of the adjective as an adverb, as at first (780-781).

On the other hand, the masculine or feminine with an adverb may be used substantively.

Nouns with a possessive pronoun take the article only when they refer to a definite individual, as this anger of yours.

It usually has a demonstrative force, and its absence does not mark a noun as indefinite, as , , sing, goddess, the wrath of the son of Peleus, Achilles.

The Personal Pronouns

The nominative of the personal pronouns is used mainly for emphasis and contrast, as but do you consider. If the subject is unemphatic, the pronoun is usually omitted, as thus he spoke (761).

The oblique cases of the third personal pronoun are anaphoric, that is, they have an antecedent previously expressed to which they refer, when unaccented; but when they are accented they have their original reflexive use, as she hurled her son from her, and the Achaeans trust in him.

[pg. 325]

Demonstrative Pronouns

The demonstrative pronouns are thus distinguished:

  • 1) (), , is used of something remote from the speaker.
  • 2) , , differs from , (), , etc., in that it usually marks a contrast in objects, but does not distinguish them as near and far, present and absent, etc.
  • 3) The compounds of , , are used of something near the speaker, or of something associated with him.
  • 4) is used of something which has been mentioned already, or else of something of particular interest or concern to the second person.
  • 5) , , in addition to being employed as a relative and as a personal pronoun is used to mark a contrast.
  • 6) in all its cases regularly means self, but at times may mean same; it is regularly intensive and is used especially to contrast a man or an object with other less important details, as clothing, weapons, and appurtenances of various kinds.

Possessive Pronouns

The possessive pronouns are as a rule equivalent to the possessive genitive of the personal pronoun, as = my child.

The Interrogative Pronouns

The interrogative , who? which? what? may be either substantive or adjective, and may be used in either direct or indirect questions.

The Indefinite Pronoun

The indefinite , some (one), something, any (one), anything may be either substantive or adjective, but is sometimes almost the equivalent of the English indefinite article, a(n), as let us ask a seer.

Relative Pronouns

A relative agrees with its antecedent in gender and number, but its case depends upon the construction of the clause in which it stands, as , sing the wrath which caused woes.

[pg. 326]

The antecedent of the relative may be omitted when it can easily be supplied from the context, especially when it is indefinite, as , it is better to take away the gifts (of that man) whoever speaks against you.

The antecedent is sometimes attracted into the relative clause. It then agrees in case with the relative.

Prepositions

Most prepositions were originally adverbs (chiefly local), and are often so employed in Homer (without case), as but therein, below, by his side.

They are used both with nouns and verbs, but are often separated from the words they modify, sometimes following them. This separation in the case of verbs has been incorrectly named tmesis ( cutting), as and he enjoined a stern command (upon him), where is to be taken with as part of the verbal idea, and darkness came on, where must be joined with .

Dissyllabic prepositions regularly have the accent on the ultima, but in two cases they take the accent on the penult:

  • 1) When they follow the word modified (with the exception of , , , ), as for which I underwent great toil, upon the shore of the sea.
  • 2) When a preposition stands for itself compounded with a verb, as , , , , (all compounded with ), and for the imperative of stand up! up!

Prepositions are used with the genitive, dative, and accusative cases; some are used with all three cases, some with only two, and some with only one.

They are used to emphasize or to define more clearly certain case relations. Of course the prepositions do not "govern" these cases, but the cases take the prepositions.

The genitive with prepositions primarily denotes that from which something proceeds, the dative that in or by which something is or is done, the accusative that toward, over, along, or upon which motion occurs.

[pg. 327]

The primary relations expressed by prepositions are those of place and time, but they may express cause, origin, agency, condition, purpose, and various other relations.

Prepositions are used in forming compound verbs, many of which, particularly those compounded with , , and , are construed with the dative.

With the genitive alone are used the following:

  • instead of
  • off, from, away from
  • () out of, from
  • before

And the following, known as improper prepositions:

  • near, close
  • between
  • without
  • until
  • , opposite, facing
  • () apart from
  • straight to
  • () (from) behind
  • behind
  • back from
  • () on account of
  • () before, in front of
  • by will of
  • () before
  • without
  • far (from)
  • within
  • far (from)

together with several others not so common.

With the dative alone are used: (), in, and () with.

With the accusative alone are used () into, to, - to.

With the genitive and accusative are used: through, on account of, over, on behalf of, and down (through).

The following are used with the genitive, dative, and accusative:

  • around, about, on both sides.
  • (up)on, up through, along.
  • (up)on, to, toward, against.
  • with, after.
  • beside, to the side of, from beside.
  • around, concerning.
  • toward, with reference to.
  • under, by means of.

Syntax of the Verb

General

A transitive verb is one whose action passes over to an object in the accusative, as sing the wrath, he kept entreating the Achaeans.

An intransitive verb is one whose action does not pass over to an object, as he came.

In verbs with both first and second tenses (first aorist, second aorist, first perfect, second perfect, etc.), the first tense is usually transitive (often causative, 1069), the second intransitive.

The active voice denotes the subject as acting, as he kindled a plague up through the camp.

The passive voice denotes the subject as being acted upon, as but the will of Zeus was being accomplished.

The middle voice denotes the subject as acting reflexively:

  • 1) upon itself, as I persuade myself (obey), I show myself (appear).
  • 2) for itself, as I call for myself, summon.
  • 3) upon something belonging to itself, or in which it has a special interest, as I loose my own, ransom.

It is often difficult to distinguish in translation between the active and middle, but the action of the middle always has some reference, either direct or indirect, to the subject, and the subject has an interest in, or is affected by the action.

Some verbs are used at times in a causative sense, that is, the subject causes something to be done by another, as let us cause Chryses to go on board (864).

Sometimes the present tense indicates that an action is only attempted; this is called the conative present, as striving to win.

When an active verb which takes two accusatives (1020) becomes passive, the accusative of the thing is retained, while the accusative of the person becomes the subject, as O thou clothed in shamelessness!

The tenses denote time of action and kind of action.

[pg. 329]

The time of action is indicated by the tenses only in the indicative.

The present is denoted by the present tense, and by the perfect.

The past is denoted by the imperfect, aorist, and pluperfect. The future is denoted by the future and the future perfect.

Continued or repeated action is denoted by the present, the imperfect, and (occasionally) the future.

Completed action denoting a permanent state is indicated by the perfect, pluperfect, and future perfect.

Action that simply takes place is indicated by the aorist and (sometimes) the future.

The imperfect denotes the continuance of action in past time, customary or repeated action, as , I loosed, was loosing, kept loosing, was accustomed to loose.

The aorist indicative denotes the simple occurrence of an action in past time, as I loosed, did loose.

Inceptive aorist

The aorist of verbs denoting a state or a condition, or continued action, usually denotes the entrance into the state, or the beginning of the action, as he fell to weeping.

The aorist is often used to express a general truth. It is then called a gnomic aorist, and is considered a primary tense, as , whoever obeys the gods, him they especially hear.

The future ordinarily denotes that an action will take place later; but may express desire or a command.

The perfect regularly denotes a state or a condition (usually as the result of completed action), and should be translated by the present, as I prefer, (who) dost protect.

Moods

The adverbs and () are often used to qualify the meaning of the moods; they are used in two ways:

  • 1) In independent clauses they are used with the subjunctive, the optative, and with the past and future tenses of the indicative; and also with the participle and infinitive, when they represent the independent indicative and optative.
  • 2) In dependent clauses, usually with the subjunctive.
[pg. 330]

These adverbs usually give a touch of indefiniteness to the clause in which they stand. They have no exact equivalent in English. When they appear in the conclusion of conditional sentences, they are usually translated by could, or would, in English.

The subjunctive with these adverbs is used almost the same as the future indicative, or the potential optative (1105).

They are used in simple sentences and in the apodosis (conclusion) of complex sentences to express limitation by circumstances or conditions.

They are regularly found in final clauses referring to the future.

They are usually found in conditional clauses in the optative and in the subjunctive, when the governing verb is future, or in a mood which implies futurity.

They are not ordinarily used in conditional, relative, and temporal clauses with the subjunctive in comparisons and similes, or when they refer to events which occur repeatedly or at an indefinite time, or when they refer to sayings which have a general application.

The Moods in Simple Sentences

THE INDEPENDENT INDICATIVE WITHOUT OR ()

Without or () the indicative mood simply states a fact, either positively or negatively, asks a question, or makes an exclamation.

An unattainable wish which refers to the present or to the past is expressed by a past tense of the indicative with (), or ; the negative is .

[pg. 331]

To express an unattainable wish, ought is used with the present infinitive to denote present time and continued past action, or with the aorist infinitive to denote past time.

THE INDEPENDENT INDICATIVE WITH or ()

The aorist (and sometimes the imperfect) indicative is used with or () to denote past possibility, probability, necessity, or a cautious statement.

The past tenses of the indicative may be used with or () to denote unreality.

or () may be used with the future indicative with a conditional or limiting meaning.

THE INDEPENDENT SUBJUNCTIVE WITHOUT OR ()

The subjunctive without or () is used in the first person, present and aorist, to express a desire or a request (hortatory subjunctive), as let us ask some seer.

The aorist subjunctive is used in the second and third persons (and sometimes in the first) with in prohibitions, as let me not come upon you.

The present and aorist subjunctive are used in the first person (rarely in the third) in deliberative questions as to what may be done advantageously or with propriety.

The subjunctive is frequently used as nearly the equivalent of the future indicative, and refers to some future event. It is usually qualified by or (), and the negative is .

THE INDEPENDENT OPTATIVE WITHOUT OR ()

The independent optative without or () is used to express a wish that something may happen, as may the gods grant to you.

The potential optative (1105), which regularly takes or (), is occasionally found without either.

The optative is employed at times to express a command, a request, or an exhortation, being practically equivalent to the imperative.

[pg. 332]

THE INDEPENDENT OPTATIVE WITH or ()

With or () the optative is used to express a future action as dependent upon circumstances or conditions. This is called the potential optative, and is usually to be translated by might, could, would, etc.

The Imperative

The imperative expresses a command, or a request; the negative is .

The Infinitive

  • 1) The only tenses which occur in the infinitive are the present, future, aorist, perfect, and future perfect. The middle and passive differ in form in the aorist only.
  • 2) In the subjunctive, optative, imperative, and infinitive, the tenses do not of themselves indicate time.
  • 3) The present in these moods denotes an action simply as continued.
  • 4) The aorist denotes an action simply as brought to pass.
  • 5) The perfect denotes an action simply as completed.
  • 6) The subject of an infinitive is usually in the accusative, but may be omitted when it is the subject of the leading verb, or its direct or indirect object.
  • 7) The infinitive may be the subject of a verb, especially an impersonal one, or ().
  • 8) It may be the object of a verb, especially verbs indicating wish, command, advice, consent, attempt, and the like.
  • 9) The infinitive may depend upon adjectives or substantives, especially those denoting ability, fitness, willingness, or have a similar meaning to verbs which take the infinitive (1107, 7).
  • 10) The infinitive also may express purpose; the negative is .
  • 11) The infinitive is used also to express a command with the nominative of the second person, or with the accusative of the third person for the subject if expressed; the subject may be omitted. In this usage it is the equivalent of the imperative.

The Participle

The participle has only the present, future, aorist, perfect, and future perfect tenses. It is used attributively as an adjective to modify a noun, or the noun may be omitted and the participle (usually with the pronoun, , , ) may be used as a substantive. Such participles usually indicate time present, past, or future relatively to the time of the main verb.

[1]The aorist participle may denote time contemporaneous with the action of the main verb, as she took the cup with a smile. [2]On the other hand, the present participle may express time previous to the action of the main verb, as leading Chryses on board he seated her.
[pg. 333]

The participle may express:

  • 1) Time, as when he had risen among them Achilles addressed them.
  • 2) Cause, as because she loved them both.
  • 3) Manner or means.
  • 4) Condition.
  • 5) Purpose or desire (usually the future participle), as (desiring) to ransom his own daughter; (desiring) to fight, for the purpose of fighting.
  • 6) Concession, as even though you are my wife.
  • 7) Attendant circumstance.

The Greek often employs a participle where we should use a relative clause, as the gods who have Olympian homes.

A noun and a participle, not closely connected grammatically with the rest of the sentence, may stand by themselves in the genitive in the construction known as the genitive absolute. See 994.

This construction arose from the use of the genitive modified by a participle, where the genitive was dependent upon some word in the main construction of the sentence, and many cases are on the border line between the absolute and the dependent constructions.

COMPOUND SENTENCES

Asyndeton, or the omission of conjunctions between independent elements of a sentence, is often used to mark lively and rapid descriptions.

[pg. 334]

Parataxis, or cordination, was often employed where one would expect a subordinate construction. 1028, note.

SUBORDINATE CONSTRUCTIONS

Purpose Clauses

Clauses which denote purpose or final clauses are introduced by the final particles , (), , , ; the negative is .

Purpose clauses take the subjunctive after primary (816) tenses, the optative (occasionally the subjunctive) after secondary tenses.

The subjunctive sometimes takes or (), especially with , (), and .

Object Clauses

The two main types of object clauses are:

  • 1) Object clauses with verbs of effort.
  • 2) Object clauses with verbs of fear.

() (sometimes and ) is used to introduce object clauses with verbs of effort. These clauses take the future indicative after both primary and secondary tenses (816). The negative is .

With verbs of effort object clauses may take the construction of purpose clauses, with () and the subjunctive or optative.

With verbs of caution negative object clauses take the construction of clauses with verbs of effort or with verbs of fear.

With verbs of effort, object clauses may take the subjunctive with after (), and sometimes after .

With verbs meaning to consider, plan, try, the subjunctive with or without (), or the optative is used. These object clauses do not take the future indicative.

The subjunctive, optative, or the future indicative, with () (() in the negative) may follow verbs of will or desire, instead of the infinitive which is the usual construction after these verbs.

[pg. 335]

OBJECT CLAUSES AFTER VERBS OF FEAR

With verbs of fear, which refer to the future, object clauses have the subjunctive after primary tenses, and the optative (sometimes the subjunctive) after secondary tenses (816).

With or () , the subjunctive or optative may be used to indicate a possible object of fear. The aorist subjunctive may refer to past time, as I fear lest she has beguiled you.

The indicative with ( in the negative) is used to express fear which refers to the present or past time. The aorist is employed in this construction.

Causal Clauses

Causal clauses are introduced by , , , , , , (), , , and .

Causal clauses which denote a fact regularly have the indicative after both primary and secondary tenses.

Causal clauses which denote an alleged or a supposed reason have the optative after secondary tenses.

Result Clauses (Consecutive Clauses)

Clauses of result are introduced by various words, some of the most common being , , , ().

These clauses may employ either the infinitive or the finite verb:

  • 1) The infinitive is used to indicate an anticipated, natural, or possible result; the negative is .
  • 2) When the finite verb is used, any form of the simple sentence may be employed. The indicative (especially in the aorist) is the form most commonly used, denoting the actual result of the action of the principal verb; the negative is .

Conditional Clauses

A conditional sentence regularly consists of two principal elements:

  • 1) The condition, denoting a supposed or assumed (if) case, called the protasis.
  • 2) The conclusion, denoting what follows if the condition is realized, called the apodosis.
[pg. 336]

and are used to introduce conditional clauses, in the indicative and optative.

, () (), are used to introduce conditional clauses in the subjunctive.

In the conclusion or () is employed with the optative to indicate possibility, and with the past tenses of the indicative to indicate the unfulfillment of the condition, or repetition.

The negative of the condition is ; of the conclusion it is when the conclusion is considered a fact if the condition be true.

Present unreal conditional sentences have with the optative in the condition, and with the optative in the conclusion.

Past unreal conditional sentences have the aorist or imperfect indicative in the condition, and in the conclusion either the aorist or imperfect indicative with or (), or the present or aorist optative with or (). The imperfect of unreal conditions represents past time.

More vivid future conditions have:

  • 1) , with the subjunctive in the condition, and in the conclusion either the future indicative or some other form referring to future time.
  • 2) The subjunctive with () in both condition and conclusion.
  • 3) (Rarely) (), () with the future in the condition.

Less vivid future conditions have (), , with the optative in the condition, and in the conclusion may have the present indicative, the simple future indicative, the future indicative with (), the hortatory subjunctive, the subjunctive with or (), or the optative, with the same force as the optative with or ().

Present general conditions have () with the subjunctive in the condition, and the present indicative or its equivalent in the conclusion.

[pg. 337]

Past general conditions have with the optative in the condition, and the imperfect indicative or its equivalent in the conclusion.

Ordinary relative clauses, which define more closely a definite antecedent, have the constructions of other simple sentences, except () or may be used with the future.

Relative clauses of purpose have the subjunctive (usually with ()) after primary tenses, and the optative after secondary tenses, although the future indicative may be used.

More vivid future conditional relative clauses have the subjunctive, usually with or (), and sometimes the future with or ().

Less vivid future conditional relative clauses have the optative with or () in the main clause, and sometimes have or () with the optative in the relative clause.

Present generalizing relative clauses usually have or () with the subjunctive in the relative clause, or the present indicative or an equivalent in the main clause.

Past generalizing relative clauses have the optative in the relative clause, and the imperfect indicative or its equivalent in the main clause.

Temporal Clauses

Temporal clauses are introduced by the temporal conjunctions , (), , , , (), ; , , () ; (()), (()).

Temporal clauses which refer to the future or to indefinite present time have the subjunctive with or ().

Temporal clauses which refer to future time have or () with the optative in the temporal clause, and may have the future indicative, or the subjunctive with or () in the main clause.

Indirect Questions

Indirect questions keep the mood and tense of direct questions, after primary tenses (the indicative, the past indicative with , the deliberative subjunctive, or the potential optative with or ()). After secondary tenses they may keep the mood and tense of direct questions, but generally change to the optative.

[pg. 338]

Indirect Discourse

The kind of the leading verb or expression in a sentence involving indirect discourse determines the construction:

  • 1) Verbs of saying have either the infinitive or a () clause.
  • 2) Verbs of thinking and believing usually take the infinitive.
  • 3) Verbs of knowing, learning, perceiving, hearing, showing, and the like, usually have the participle, but may have a () clause.

Clauses in indirect discourse introduced by or , after primary tenses keep the mood and tense of the direct form unchanged.

Indicatives and subjunctives without or () usually become optative after secondary tenses, but may remain unchanged.

Subordinate verbs after primary tenses keep their original mood and tense.

The optative is not employed in indirect discourse except in indirect questions (1153). After both primary and secondary tenses in principal clauses, the same past tense is used that would have been employed in an independent clause, from the speaker's point of view. After the secondary tenses the future is generally represented by with the infinitive.

PROSODY

Rules of Quantity, the Hexameter

Every vowel which has the circumflex accent is long (537).

The vowel of the ultima in every word having the circumflex on the penult is short (545).

If a long penult has the acute accent, then the ultima must be long also.

If the ultima is short and the penult has the acute accent, then the penult must be short also.

If the antepenult has the accent, the vowel of the ultima must be short (544).

Exceptions to these rules are to be found only in the cases of the diphthongs and , when final, which are then considered short (except in the optative and ) for the purpose of accent but must be counted long when marking the feet of the verse (547).

Apparent exceptions to these rules are to be found in the case of certain classes of compounds, as , , , , , , , , , etc., where the primary form is accented without considering the following enclitic as an integral part of the word.

Most exceptions to the rules of quantity are only apparent.

If an apparently short final syllable stands where a long one is expected, it is probable that:

  • 1) The pause of the caesura (1185) or diaeresis (1188) fills out the time required for the foot, allowing the same freedom as at the end of a verse, or
  • 2) The following word has lost an initial , making the preceding syllable long by position. For various forms of metrical lengthening, see 525, 566, 571, 1168.
[pg. 340]

Metrical Lengthening

Syllables containing a short vowel, followed by a single consonant, or by another vowel, are lengthened under the verse ictus (1183). Compare 525, 566, 571, 1167.

Special Rules for Determining the Length of Syllables by their Position in Hexameter

If a long syllable is followed by a short, then the next syllable must be short also.

If a short syllable is followed by a long, then the preceding syllable must be short also.

The first syllable of each foot must be long, and is to be given slightly more stress than the other half of the foot (1183).

When a word ends in a short vowel (and sometimes the diphthongs and ), and the next word begins with a vowel, the final vowel of the first word is regularly elided (575).

When a word ends in a long vowel or a diphthong and the next word begins with a vowel, the long final vowel or diphthong is regularly shortened.

[*]Sometimes a long vowel or diphthong is shortened when followed by a vowel within the same word.

If a word ends in a short vowel and the next word originally began with vau (), elision ordinarily does not take place (580), but may, as = .

If a word ends in a long vowel or a diphthong and the next word originally began with a vau (), the long final vowel or diphthong ordinarily remains long.

If a word ends in a long vowel or a diphthong and has the verse-accent on it, the long vowel or diphthong may remain long, even though the next word begins with a vowel. Cf. 1168.

When a word ending in a vowel is followed by a word beginning with a vowel, the result is hiatus. Hiatus is ordinarily avoided in poetry either 1) by elision; 2) by the use of movable consonants, 561-563; 3) by the shortening of a final long vowel or diphthong, 1173; 4) by crasis or synizesis, 586-587.

[pg. 341]

Hiatus may be allowed 1) when there is a distinct pause in sense (diaeresis or caesura 1185-1189) between the vowels which produce it; 2) when the verse-accent (ictus) falls on the long vowel or diphthong which is followed by another vowel; 3) when elision has already taken place; 4) after or ; 5) when a long vowel or diphthong is shortened (weak or improper hiatus).

The metre of the Homeric poems is the dactylic (sometimes called the heroic) hexameter, the most common of all Greek verse.

There are six feet to the verse, the first five being either dactyls (that is, one long followed by two shorts ), or its equivalent, the spondee (that is, two longs ). The sixth foot is always a spondee.

In dactylic hexameter the ictus (verse accent) is always on the first syllable of each foot (1183).

The fifth foot is usually a dactyl, only about one verse in twenty having a spondee in this place, which gives the verse a movement slower than usual. It is then called a spondaic verse.

In each foot one part is distinguished from the other by a slight stress of voice, called the ictus (1171, 1181).

The final syllable of a verse may be either long or short, but as there is a slight pause here, the final syllable in hexameter is always considered long, making the last foot of the verse always a spondee, 1180.

Whenever a word ends within a foot, it is called caesura. If this coincides with a pause in the verse, it is called the caesura of the verse. The caesura is employed with great skill in the Homeric poems to make the verse more melodious and to aid in its recital.

There is almost always a caesura in the third foot. It occurs either after the first syllable of the foot, or else between the two short syllables.

The pause after the first syllable is called the masculine caesura, that after the second the feminine.

Whenever the end of a word coincides with the end of a foot, it is called diaeresis. When this falls with a pause, it is called the diaeresis of the verse.

[pg. 342]

The most important diaeresis is the one which comes at the end of the fourth foot. From its common employment in pastoral poetry it is called the bucolic diaeresis.

For metrical purposes all vowels and syllables of Greek words may be divided into long and short.

The rhythm of Greek verse is based upon the regular succession of long and short syllables.

To obtain facility in reading the verse, a considerable quantity of it should be memorized, special attention being paid to the quantity (that is, twice as much time should be given to each long syllable as to a short), and the pauses should be carefully observed. Although English verse is primarily accentual rather than quantitative, still the memorizing of a few lines of English dactylic hexameter (Longfellow's "Evangeline,"[1]

This is the forest primaeval, the murmuring pines and the hemlocks,
Bearded with moss, and in garments green, indistinct in the twilight,
Stand like Druids of eld, with voices sad and prophetic,
Stand like harpers hoar, with beards that rest on their bosoms.
for example, mediocre though it be) will materially aid in getting the swing and the movement of the Greek hexameter.

[pg. 343] [*] Words preceded by an asterisk (*) are assumed forms; those followed by an asterisk are Attic, analogous to known Homeric forms, but not found in Homer; those followed by a double asterisk (**) are Attic not analogous to Homeric forms; those followed by a dagger () are not Epic, or Attic, but are Ionic, or Lyric; those followed by a hyphen (-) are stems (626-630).
